The chicken and all of the vegetables just weren't up to par-everything was bland and tasted...like...americanized Ethiopian food. There was a pickled, gingered taste to everything. 

I'll stick to the spicy fare and fun atmosphere of Club Waziema.
author: S F.

description:
I first had Ethiopian back in Miami and I am a big fan of eating with my hands and food packing tons of spices. We had tried Assab before and our stomachs disagreed with it and we had been meaning to try what most people tend to agree is the best Ethiopian place in the city.

Ambiance (3): Small, homey, whole in the wall. Good to go.

Food (4): The amount of spices was good, the portions were good, but the injerra was just ok, which to me is critical for Ethiopian. I don't remember the exact names of the dishes, but we had a lamb, the lentils, chicken, and beef. The lamb was the best as usual. The Ethiopian beer was pretty good and it was the first time I had the opportunity to try it. It's a little sweet FYI.

Service (3): Dependable, friendly, and timely. 

Value (5): Great food for a very low price. 

Overall: Best Ethiopian place in the city so far. We are going to try the place on Divis soon and see how that one is.
author: Alvaro H.

description:
Great food!  Great wine!  Great prices!  Friendly staff!

What more could you want in a restaurant?  Their platters cater to meat- and vegetarian-oriented palates alike.  You can order 1 or 2 dishes that are sizable for the price or you can have a sampler platter and try smaller portions of more dishes (price & portion-size being based on how many people you are ordering for).

AWESOME AWESOME!  One of the great benefits of living in the City!

GO AXUM!
author: Mike G.

description: Obviously a popular destination, since it's always packed, and clearly many of the diners aren't residents of the lower Haight. It's named after Ethiopia's most ancient city, selected as the capital of the Kingdom of Aksum by the queen of Sheba some one thousand years before Christ. Dishes are served on a large piece of injera, the Ethiopian pancake-like bread, with a refreshingly tangy salad. Ideal for a group is the combo allowing you to sample all five vegetarian entrees - including spicy mushrooms simmered with tomatoes, onions, and garlic, spinach and jalapenos, and chickpeas pureed with onions - for only $32.00. Among the meat options, tender lamb sauteed with onions, jalapeno peppers, garlic, tomatoes, and spices is the standout. Ethiopian lager, stout, and honey wine are available.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
First of all, this place rules simply because of it's name. Got a question? Why don't you AXUM?

Just don't axum for more water because they'll never get around to it. But why would you want the water anyway? It's tepid and may or may nor may not have a colony of Sea Monkeys living in it. Bring your own bottle of water here.

I've eaten at nearly every damn stupid restaurat in the Lower Haight, and I've always shied away from Axum. Although I am an inquisitive person with quite a few questions, I just never found the time to axum. (hi-oh!)

Maybe it was something about the inviting bars on the windows the finally lured me in; I dunno. The food...eh, it was okay. Nothing to call home to mom about my any means. Flavorful enough and delivered to the table promptly. It was a little bit too runny for me, and I kept trying to catch it but it was too quick. The waitress probably thought I was "differently abled" after cleaning up.

If you live in the Lower Haight, or just end up eating there all the time like I do, I'd advise that Axum be one of the last stops on your cuisine-o-rama rampage in that 'hood.
author: Pamela D.

description:
In my opinion the best in the city at the moment (i shed a tear when my favorite on ocean ave closed) and i have been eating ethiopian forever.

Average price, but the deal is in the portions. No matter how many dishes you order, and even if there are only two of you, they fill a large large injera plate to the brim.

Try the ethiopian black tea.
author: Sasha T.

description:
Axum has some tasty Ethiopian food!

mmmm...  the yellow and the brown  -  plus the meat eaters didn't seem to be raving about hte lamb thing so I second Miri's suggestion that vegetarian is the way to go here.
author: lisa g.

description:
I love eating with my fingers!  

As my king ney-ney says, "stick with the yellow and brown" - we think they're lentils - vegetarian is the way to go here.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description: I love this place.  Food is quick and amazing, prices are much cheaper than any other Ethiopian place. Strongly suggested.
author: Gökçe Ç.

description:
This place should have a sign outside that says "no teeth required" since meals are served puree-style on giant plastic platters  I imagine that they have a giant grinder in the kitchen that smashes up the lentils, peas, cabbage, spinach, chicken, etc. since everything we ordered had the consistency of mush and has no discernable spicing.  The spongey, clammy-feeling, sour-tasting bread was pretty  gross.  The ambience?  Dirty lino floors, plastic topped tables that wobbled like crazy, melamine plates and plastic tumblers.  Oh, and we also got one paper napkin apiece from the surly waitress.   We got there at 5:45PM, first customers there, and waited 30 minutes for our gruel.

Not even worth it - I considered going to Burger Joint after we left, but realized that I needed to find a bathroom - FAST - after consuming Axum's pap.
author: .Hon H.

description:
I take no one here but Boots.

You see, the hardest aspect of eating at Axum is rationing the injera bread that comes on the side. I always run out and by the end I'm sticking my fingers into the oh-so-good veggie platter with tibse beef (or zighine) that has become my "usual", trying to use the injera on the bottom, with food running down my hands, and well, it isn't pretty.

I don't want you to see me like this. Look away.

Oh, if you are into stout beer, try the Hakim stout, it's quite good! Where can I buy a case?

[Update: Oct 2007]
Hakim Stout is no longer available and had my first bad meal (I've been going here for over 10 years!). The Tibse Beef was really tough and chewy and the Alecha (cabbage especially) had a strong detergent taste. I'm not sure what happened there... Unrinsed pots?
author: Mister X.

description:
Solid 3.
Good food but not as great as Addis Red Sea in Boston, MA (my standard).
OK honey wine. 
Amazing server. One gentleman for all of us. He was so busy but he remembered everything perfectly.
17 for veggie combo of 5 different vegetarian options and salad
+ 5 for a glass of honey wine on VALENTINE'S DAY!
Quick service. No reservations needed and 100% clean record by the city.
We found street parking pretty easily. Oh, and the toilet was stopped up but not in an uber gross way. The rest of the bathroom was clean and yeah. 
We'll prolly be back, but not definitely.
author: Abi W.

description:
I've walked by this place numberous times, but have only peeked in. Tonite my friend Matt was coming over to drop of some bike stuff and grab a beer. I suggested grabbing some food as well and he was game. 

So we roll towards the Haight and I'm asking him what he'd like to eat and then I remember...ooohhh, Axum Cafe. I been wanting to try it for quite some time. I say do you like Ethiopian and he's like yup. Done deal.

We walk in and seat ourselves. The host, a kid whose about 10, comes over with a menu almost immediately. In less than a minute we have water at our table as well. So far so good. 

We chat a bit, then peek at the menu. I'm like oh they have beer on tap! Sweet ;-) Food, we picked the TSEBI HE DERHO (chicken drumsticks in a mole like sauce), the  TIBSIE LAMB(spicy), ALICHA ATER (pureed chickpeas) and a pitcher of Stella to accompany the meal.  

The chicken was tasty, done up in a brown sauce, which reminded me a lot of mexican mole. The lamb was our favorite, spicy, tender and delicious! The chickpeas were good, but I'd try something that looks less like bile next time ;-) The Stella was light and did not detract from the flavor of the food. The injera was thin, more like crepes, but tasted fresh. I like when injera is more sourdoughy tasting.

Will definitely be back here. I liked this place a bit better than Wazeima only because of the spicy lamb dish. I'm mexican so I need my food to be spicy and Axum delivered big time. Can't wait to try the other Tibsie dishes.
author: isaias J.

description:
If you have just had a deep tissue massage and want to preserve the healthiness of your day continue on to Axum and get the mixed vegetarian platter.  It's only $8.00 and if you can finish all that food, well, cheers to you and your huge enormous gut.  

You must be patient here, the staff does what they want at their own pace, and I had to temper myself a couple of times when I sat waving around my empty water glass (recall the deep tissue massage).  Eventually, however, everything I needed was taken care of, and the food was fresh, yummy and cheap. 

Great alone dinner spot with a Guardian.  Cheers!
author: Claire C.

description: A modest little place with the bestest ethiopian food (not that I ever had it before) but we shared a vegitarian platter and it was the bestest thing ever. The waitstaff was friendly, the prices are LOW and I am craving a visit back there right now!!
author: Nikki M.

description: I love Ethiopian food, and by residing in North Oakland I am graced by several great restaurants. Axum does not hold a candle to the worst one in Oakland. Not only is the food far sub-par, (dry, under and overcooked), but a few waiters and the manager are catastrophically rude. This is the only Ethiopian restaurant I have been to in the City, but I implore you to treat yourself to any place on Telegraph in Oakland (like Cafe Colucci or Asmara) for excellent Ethiopian food. You can make a great day of it!
author: Joanna M.

description:
I think a negative review reflects badly on the reviewer not the business...
whatever to scnizmjismwhateverlearn 
about it...i'm a fan just because i hate snivelers that don't like the truth...
author: jonathan b.

description:
The whole point of Ethiopian food is to eat with your fingers.  For those yelpers who have to have silverware, simple solution, don't eat here.  Take it home!

The food is top notch, the bread may be an acquired taste, but the tang of it offsets the burn of the food.  All the stews are excellent and although I'm not a fan of the potatoes and cabbage dish the mushroom and spinach dishes are great.  The lamb stew is also good and the lentils deserve every rave on yelp.  

Other plusses the honeyed wine and the Ethiopian beer.  Both worth a try.

Remember this is the lower Haight so parking is non existent.  Or use some of the money you save [at $10 a person this place is a bargain] and spring for the cab ride.
author: Aj D.

description:
Wow...  where to start... how about with your hands?

Eat some of the green, now some of the dark green, some of the brown, oh damn, did I just eat my napkin?  Oh no, that's injera.  The beef looks like dog food but tastes 500 times better (not that I've been eating dog food lately, ok, ok, ok not that I've been eating THAT much dog food lately).

I order an Ethiopian beer.  "It's just repackaged PBR, dude."  That may be, but there's nothing like washing down tasty beef, fish and injera with a cold beer.  "This stuff is great!" I say, as I continue to mop up everything on the plate with injera, including the lettuce and tomato garnish and the last of the sauce the beef came in.  I sit back, satisfied.  

Sub average short stories suck, I know, so here's the summary already:  Axum Cafe is some good eats.  If you have one of those friends who is always complaining about trying something different, take them here.  Not only will your dining partner thank you, but you'll likely return a few more times.  For probably around $15 each, you guys can get stuffed on some great food.  I know Ethiopia isn't frequently hailed as a seafood giant, but I recommend trying the fish.  It's a little pricey but I would steal the recipe for preparing it if I didn't fear the owner's 24 hour evil eye.  Also the veggie is never all you can eat, but I think it's tastier than Waizema.

Yeah the service is a bit like your trip the bathroom the next day (crappy) and the prices can be a little scary especially if you're really hungry but Axum is one of the better sit down places you can enjoy on Lower Haight.

Oh, and my stomach conquered the injera.  Harmless.  And you guys call yourself eaters?
author: Steven R.

description:
My first 'hood was Lower Haight and my first Ethiopian was Axum. 

I spent the afternoon talking up the place to my date, and was really excited to get in. But something magical happened in the couple of years since I ate here last: it turned into a really crappy restaurant.

The waiter took forever to take our order, and then forgot to put it in. Nothing like watching people get seated, get served, and finish eating while you're waiting for your meal. When I finally got him to acknowledge me, he brought us our rapidly approaching tepid plate, which wasn't what we'd ordered, and decided to bring us our napkins at the exact same time that he brought us our check.

David Foster Wallace said that it's important to have someone to hate in every situation. It helps conversation along, and it polarizes everyone in the room, making them comrades of a sort. This is true. My date went well, partially because we were able to find fantastically common ground in our loathing of the service. I'm not going to say that the poor service got me laid, but I will say that it very well may have helped. I'm funny when I'm annoyed, and women don't like me for my looks.

The food gets one star because we were hungry and it was there. Kind of an "any port in a storm" kind of sitch.
author: jason l.

description:
If you are blindfolded and fed this food, you will think, mmm tasty, kinda soft and mushy, kinda oily, kind spicy...is that a sponge in my mouth?

If you decide to wash your hands in the bathroom before the meal, and if you eat here, you should also insist that all your dinner companions do the same or bring sterilized surgical gloves since everyone is expected to stick their nasty mitts into the same communal plate....excuse I have to vomit a little at the thought...

ok I'm back.

Yes, even if you are at a big table with several people, you get one giant pan where everyone digs in with fingers...oh no, I gotta hurl again...

sorry...that was it.

The bathroom is dirty, the walls are dirty, the door is dirty...the food is, tasty. but the tables are dirty and you can bet your ass that the hands of your dinner companion are dirty...they better be!

The yucky spongy bread expands in your tummy about an hour after you eat...you WILL look like you are 9 months pregnant. 

Oh, I forgot, the service is NOT friendly!

Yuck yuck yuck and yuck.
author: Nilu r.

description: The food is okay, but not made to order.  The owner seems to value efficiency over friendliness, which is great if you want to be in and out in 15 minutes, but leaves you feeling rushed otherwise. (There were several empty tables, so it wasn't a space issue.)  Still,  might have been 4 stars with better ambiance and friendlier service.
author: Rami M.

description:
Awsome! Ask for a fork and stop whining!

Tastes great
Cheap
Go on sunday night after five for great parking
Saturday good place to watch hipsters but go early
Sunday you will hear the owner playing an ethiopean guitar while watching abc nightly news....
author: Bubble B.

description:
This is a good place to start if you've never had Ethiopian food before. Guaranteed, when you take a friend to Ethiopian who has never had it, they make at least one (1) joke regarding the dearth of food in the actual country of origin and how they would not like to eat twigs and sand.  It's not really LOL anymore. And they will no longer LOL either after they try it, because it's delicious, and we take delicious very seriously, don't we?

The bars on the windows scare me a little, but I guess that's better than someone trying to totally break in while you are enjoying your dinner.
author: Shannon V.

description:
I was thoroughly enjoying eating with my hands when my friend pointed out that there was a massive bullet hole in the window behind me.  It's one of those things that has you looking around the walls and ceiling for the exit hole, but no joke, there was an actual gun shot fired at this restaurant.  And that, by itself, is not all that shocking.  More surprising, indeed, is that they care so little about ambiance that they wouldn't even replace that pane of glass with one that has fewer, umm.... holes in it.

Speaking of ambiance, it was also right around his third bite that my other friend came down with what can only be described as acute pronounced heartburn.  He went from 0-60 in what I assure you was no more than two bites.  One bathroom trip later and he guaranteed success, but I was as worried about him exploding as the bullet hole behind my head.

It's testament to the food that I could put all of that behind me and hand-grab the munchies like an ape.  This is good stuff, bullet holes and indigestion notwithstanding.  And they don't withstand, because after all, you can't beat stuffing face with cheap Ethiopian food.  Yum.
author: Daniel D.

description:
The Lamb Tibsie knocked my socks off. It was perfectly spiced, so I could taste the kick but wasn't crying after three bites. It also came in a nice, big portion for just $10. Exactly what I was looking for on Friday night after a long, long, long week at work. They also offer some pretty tasty, non-acidic tej (honey wine), for the authentic experience. I'll have to find out who their supplier is. 

Anyhow, I'll definitely be back. Nowhere else has made me feel like I was back in Ethiopia this way...which is extra-impressive since I've never been there.
author: Daniel M.

description:
The perfect place to take your red state friends when they are visiting. Exotic food that is hearty and easy to like AND YOU GET TO EAT ALL PRIMITIVE LIKE WITH YER HANDS N'STUFF!

Make sure to get a ginger beer, the flavor perfectly compliments the ethopian spices and your after burps will be delicious.

Don't go with marathon eaters though because everyone eats off the same plate. Runts haven't a chance to escape their runtiness.

YAY FOR NATURAL SELECTION AND SURVIVAL OF THE FATTEST!
author: merkley m.

description:
This is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the city.  I used to live a half a block away and ate there at least once a week for a year.  :)  Such a great place at an amazingly low price.  In general, I recommend you get the vegetarian platter for the number of people in your party + a meat dish to finish it off.

Friendly staff for once neighborhood exclusive now 'best of the bay' popular.
author: Chris M.

description:
I love me some Ethiopian food. 
and yes Ethiopians eat
AND they do it with their hands.
so deal with it.

This is my favorite spot for Ethiopian in the city.  The food is always spiced perfectly and super flavorful and affordable.  

I usually share the vegetarian platter for 2 containing 5 veggie items for $14. And if I'm in a meaty mood I'll add the Kitfo or the Tibsie to the "Combination of Three Veggie Entrees" meal.

mmm mmm mmmmmmmmmm ...  cheap and delicious!
author: Shayna N.

description:
Went to Axum last night with friends. I'd been once before years ago, and every time I have Ethiopian I leave asking myself "why have I waited this long?" So tasty, and as long as you're with a hygienic crew, what's not to love?

We were a party of four and we had their platter of vegetarian options, along with a big and lamb dish. 

Definitely a place to go with people you're close with already, or if you're really hungry, who you don't mind getting messy in front of. 

There were some issues with the service, and I'm not sure if it was because they were short staffed for night or something else, but  a couple of impatient hipsters made it clear, holding their bill up in the air to be noticed. Yeah, like she had somewhere else to be.
author: Jason R.

description:
I ate here with two people. We ordered 3 dishes (which arrived on one injera platter, as expected). They had the following characteristics:

* Decent injera, not very thick, but still tasty
* Spinach dish: tasty, kinda bland, nothing exciting.
* Beef dish: interesting, nothing exciting.
* Lentils dish: the winner of the 3. delicious in most ways.

Huh?:
* They served us food before they served us water.
* They served us food before they served us napkins.

Yay!:
* In the lower Haight
* FAST service
* $25 bill ($30 including cushy tip) for 3 people
author: Ashley M.

description: The food is good but the service is non-existent and we watched a cockroach crawl across the floor after we ate. Needless to say, I can't go back.I'm just going to take the extra time and go to Moya.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Killed Injera in 2 minutes...
Delisious, but I wish I had a bigger one :)))
Overall, my habesha friends keep on the tradition of a good taste! (shoot I know I know, dont discharge my roots)
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: Veggie combo did not seem to have much flavor. And I know these veggies should have flavor - and texture too. And no spicy kick? I left this place disappointed.
author: Judy L.

description:
If you haven't had Ethopian food, try it!  For all the gringos out there, your food will be served on a big sourdough tortilla-looking thing (Injera), and you will also receive a big sourdough tortilla-looking thing  to use as a "fork," which you should eat.  According to the waiter, a rookie mistake is to eat too much fork and not be able to finish all the food on the platter.  

Axum took a serious rating hit tonight by botching the drinks.  Four of the 6 beers on tap (of course, the first four I asked for...) were unavailable, the waiter being completely clueless about the situation.  Allegedly, the wine tasted like "it had been sitting around for a while," though I didn't try it myself.  

The vegetarian platter is good.  The prices are reasonable, too.  $24 will cover dinner for 2, and you'll be out for $30 if you can figure out how to get a beer.
author: Christopher S.

description:
One of my best friends from high school spent her last hour in San Francisco driving down to Axum with me so that she could get a double order of their vegetarian sampler to take back home to St. Louis with her.  It's not that they don't have Ethiopian food in St. Louis - Saaba's mom used to cook it for us back in elementary school.  But Axum's food is just good enough that you want it for your last SF meal.  Another friend came all the way from Walnut Creek to eat here.  And on her way out, she bought another order to take home FOR HER MOM.  That good.

I used to live around the corner from here, so I'd get a veggie sampler for takeout almost once a week.  Almost everything is pre-cooked, so it's ready as soon as you order.  If you stay there to eat the staff is friendly but sometimes overwhelmed by the crowds, so don't expect intimate service.  But if you want to sit and talk to your Lower Haight hipster crew, this is just the place.

However, they serve warm milk with Amaretto.  I don't care if I'm lactoce intolerant.  I'll have two.
author: Sarah S.

description: Such a deal.  Get the veggie combo and throw in lamb and chicken and it's still only $13 per person, with drinks. Don't worry about parking -- take the N-Judah and walk two blocks and you're there
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Been here at least 5 times and all of them have been good, service can be improved but the food in general is great.
Whoever cooks there likes to add a good amount of spice to their food so you have been warned.
The injera is not as spongy as other Ethiopian places I've been before.
I've read that the reason behind the sponginess of the injera is relative to the amount of time they let it ferment.
But in general it's a good place to go if you are in the city and want to try something new.
And don't forget a full bottle of honey wine!
author: Ingram S.

description:
These guys just went up a star because they had Hakim stout last night. I don't know if they always had it and I never asked or if it's something they run out of, just started carrying or what. I've been here a few times and always enjoyed my food but it never became a place to crave until last night.

I like the mushrooms and the chickpeas. Yum yum! Sometimes the spinach is spot on, other times it's a little off. I have heard really good things about the lamb if you like that kinda thing.

I've never had the injera be dry or thick always nice and moist and tangy the way I like it!
author: Allegra F.

description:
Oh, good stuff is waiting for you here.

Parking is a hassle in the area but at least friendly service is waiting for you when when you get there. Tip: go there with a small city type care (i.e.: mini, prius, civic, fiesta, etc...) for a more successful parking experience.

My favorite dish over here is the Vegetarian combo platter accompanied with hot apple cider and I'm good. Mmmm...

Now, to eat these dishes you need to use your hands so, make sure everyone who you'll be eating with washes up before the food is served.

How-to eat one of these things... tear off a little piece of the breading that will be served on the side of this 

The dishes are filling and real affordable.  i don't believe we spent more than $28 on the Vegetarian Platter and drinks for four people.  It's a good deal.

Note: This venue is handicap accessible. I've been in a wheelchair for a while now and I haven't had any problems getting a table.

All in all, in the city, we usually have a craving for Axum, Poleng Lounge, and Rotee.
author: Anita J.

description:
Probably some confirmation bias of having this place within walking distance, but this is one of the better Ethiopian places I've enjoyed.  Good food, perfectly aged injera, the driest Tej.  The first time the food was good but could've been more flavorful, so the second we asked for everything to be spicy, which brought out much richer flavors.

Beware that the portions are huge, so skip lunch if you want to finish.  The Tej honey wine clears the palate without guzzling, so there's less liquid to absorb into the injera once they're all chatting in your gut.

The service can be perfunctory, but that's as much a part of Ethiopian restaurants as the inexpensive prices.

So, if you're willing to starve yourself to finish, enjoy high spice, limited hydration, and ignore service lapses, then it's a fabulous place.  It's expectation management, but it's no different than other Ethiopian places in the negative ways, and better than most for the food, so five stars.
author: Don T.

description:
The outside is fairly plain and uninviting, but this is great Ethiopian food, make no mistake.

Very reasonably priced, the service is prompt, and the sauces/spices are excellent. The lamb dish I got was quite spicy, but I liked that. Very friendly service too. 

It's a bit small/cramped/dark on the inside, but the food more than makes up for it.
author: Mark A.

description:
A Lower Haight standard- has been feeding freaks on the cheap for years now- the food is very tasty, maybe not so refined, the service is charmingly miserable, not unlike Zocalo in that regard- but all around a very fun and affordable dining experience. 
Oh yeah, and it's basically filthy- also like Zocalo- or at least shabby, but I find that endearing.
author: Jonny A.

description:
Axum Cafe gave me the worst case of  food poisoning that I've ever had in my entire life.

I fancy myself a pretty-well iron-tummied person -- I like to order hot things, I eat peppers, I slurp down oil, I mix alcohol types within the same night -- but this place blew my ass out.  Literally.

We didn't even make it all the way back to the Kezar parking lot.  Axum's food had to leave my body.  *Now.*

And so it did.

My friend and I island-hopped from bathroom to bathroom all the way down Haight back towards the Kezar lot.  The experience affirmed my faith in humanity a bit since the notoriously not-letting-you-use-the-restroom-because-of-all-the-nouveau-hippies-and-current-homeless-in-the-damn-area-ish merchants of Haight would open their bathroom door to such a desperate sight as myself as I was caught in Axum's throes.  That part was nice in retrospect.

It is my recommendation to you that you not go to Axum Cafe under any circumstances.  There's plenty of good/interesting food nearby.  Seriously, look elsewhere for good eats.
author: Chris R.

description:
Super good, super cheap Ethiopian. Not too divey. Casual and great for conversation over a shared platter. We eat here once every week or two. Don't let the waitstaff put you off, they're quite nice once you get to know them. Quality can occasionally be uneven, but when it's good and fresh it's really good.

Tip: Go early. Seems to be more reliably "good and fresh" earlier in the evening.
author: Tom L.

description:
The bf has a fascination with "exotic", so we tried Axum.   The only other similar cuisine that we had was at Assab in Inner Richmond.  Comparatively, I liked the injera better here at Axum.  The Zinghine that I ordered had the flavor profile that I liked.  It didn't have a lot of spice, outside of garlic.  I could eat it w/o reaching for my water every five seconds. 

Some critiques:

- portions small for the price
- parking in that area can be a pain
- service is decent, but not friendly
- the food was good, but not great
- they don't have a sampler platter for the meat dishes....BOO.

It is something to try, at least once, but I don't know if we'll be back since we really don't live close to the neighborhood.

For 2 people, one shared plate with Zenghine and Tibsie Chicken and a bottle of Stewart's Ginger Beer = $23.00 (not including tip)
author: Hiromi N.

description:
The food is great, I love to eat with my hands and the honey beer just goes along perfectly with the Ethiopian spices. 

If you're starving this is the place to come! You'll get a lot of food (the injera bread expands once in your stomach, so you'll feel full no matter what) and the service is fast.
author: Polly L.

description:
Just ok.  I've had much better, but I've also had worse.
Not the largest selection and not the friendliest service.  Kinda felt like the guy was annoyed to have customers.....boy, do I wanna go back soon (not)!
Excellent Ethiopian places in Berkeley, and although I'm hardly one for traversing that bridge, it's worth it in this case.
author: Jessica L.

description:
The food is definitely okay, and I will probably eat it again, but it doesn't create any cravings or the desire to eat uncontrollably like other ethiopian places. It is no Ensarro in Oakland, which is my all time favorite place in the universe to get ethiopian.

I ordered the veggie combo to go with the lentils, spinach, and cabbage - the lentils were my favorite, but it was all good. It was definitely a lot of food for the price. The downsides were that the food was a bit cold, because they probably cooked it all earlier in the day (as evidenced by the speedy turnaround time), and the injero was a bit too thick and dry for my taste.
author: Corinne R.

description: Great food. I love the tibsie beef and vege mushroom option. This is a great neighborhood spot, family run place.
author: Adriani L.

description: Axum Cafe is yet another place I have intended to dine for a few years, and I welcomed the opportunity. As with many places on Haight, the grunge of the street diminishes the appeal and disguises its true value. We ordered the vegetarian platter for six, in order to try as much as possible. The pastes and condiments were delicious, although anyone with a mild intolerance to spice would be advised to exercise caution. The only sample I did not partake of was the lettuce - despite what certain arties alleged, I was not averse to eating it, I merely could not figure out how. Here I must warn future customers: Axum Cafe does not believe in utensils. One eats the food via bread which sometimes sticks to the fingers more than the food.
author: Marcus M.

description:
Excellent Tibsie Lamb and Beef with some flavorful puree and a refreshing salad all thrown into the same platter.

The Injera (flat, spongey bread you use to eat with) is a little on the sour side but very good regardless.

Just don't expect any attentive service, you'll have to get the host's or waiter's attention if you want any extra injera or a refill.  And if you're in a hurry to leave, be sure to ask them directly for the check or else it'll take forever for you to get it.  I think it's mostly because they want you to just relax and not rush you out the door.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I had dinner at Axum with a few friends this evening and the experience left a fairly bad taste in my mouth, as well as the stool.  The restaurant is "family style" which is nice and while the decor was plain, it was acceptable given the prices on the menu.

Food wise we ordered the vegetarian platter for six which had five different entrees and a salad.  Definitely plenty of food but of the five entrees, only two were really enjoyable: the chickpea and lentil purees.  The mushrooms were over spiced, making it difficult to eat, and the spinach and potato-cabbage entrees were tasteless and under seasoned.

Minus one star for the stomach pains I've had since eating the meal.  While I laughed earlier at the reviews on Yelp mentioning "the shits," it's unfortunately true.  This, however, may just be due to the unusual spices they use and shouldn't cloud your judgement.  But I am happy that I decided not to order meat...

Minus another star for attempting to get us to order two, three person platters when we asked for one, six person platter.  The waitress suggested that it would be easier for us to handle but I'm sure it was only done to try and get us to buy two $25 platters instead of one $45 one.

Finally, minus another star for a billing problem.  We decided to split the bill on two cards but checking our statements, there's a charge for half the meal (plus tip) as well as a full charge for the meal.  In all the hundreds of times I've gone out to eat, this is the first time I've had such a thing happen.

I'd give the place a try if only for the unusual method of eating (with your hands) but definitely pay by cash and be sure to pack a roll of Tums with you.
author: A K.

description: For $12 I ordered the second beef option on the menu (with Ethiopian spices and butter).  The food was delicious and the beef was tender.  The injera on my plate was enough though they did bring out an extra plate for each dish.  My friend thought the injera was a bit dry, as if it had been made for a while and just sitting there, but I am no injera snob.  He enjoyed his vegetarian fare and his Ethiopian beer.  There weren't too many people there at around 8:30 on a Monday night.  The male owner bought out an instrument and was absent-mindedly strumming it while watching the tv.  It sounded very bluesy.  It sounded very nice against the background of the news on Japan's tsunami and Libya's Gaddafi.
author: Walerz B.

description: The food was pureed. Like gravy. Not what it should be. Ew! No atmosphere. Where is the wait staff?! I don't plan on going back ever. (And I LOVE Ethiopian food and this place is 3 blocks from my home. Even so, I won't go back.)
author: Jennie L.

description:
I'm actually in love with this place.The food is incredible, the service is sweet and the location is pretty cool, too. You can't get much cheaper and yet the quality is oh so fine. 
I've only had the vegetable combo plate to share. If you're eating with 3 other people, it's actually worth it to order for 6 instead because it's so cheap and the left overs are deeelicious! Actually, Axum's 5 Veggie combo plate left overs make for an awesome after concert snack as well as dinner.
The Veggie plate is wonderful for even your die hard meat eaters, too. It's basically a please all.

My only beef with this place is that even though they post their hours, you never really know when they will be open. I always call in advance. They seem to have actually nailed down the usual hours lately, but still.... call first.
author: Samantha C.

description: I love this place.  The service is always top notch, the food amazing and it's budget friendly.  The shrimp dish is fantastic. Very friendly staff.
author: Clare C.

description:
I spent a fair portion of my patronage here in the bathroom. The walls are a delicate haze of yellow, and a quick whiff with an upturned nose leaves one reeling in a mix of soiled digestive juices and mixed ethiopian condiments. The mirror's fairly smashing - it bends to the side somewhat, so you get to admire yourself in a sort of what-if-i-had-a-stroke-and-my-left-side-drooped pose. The toilet itself is fairly standard - hospital-white, and comes with a bowl, cover and flusher. And for those of the delicate disposition... disposable seat covers. 

Sadly I never actually saddled the throne. Mine was more of Sunday-Church pose on a pew; knees to the ground, hands on the rim and silent-cursives to the heavens.
author: Marc M.

description: Terrible service absolutely terrible food. I never write reviews ever... But this one deserves it. The waitress (an older lady) had the MOST disgusting attitude. She was rude to us when my friend and I asked for suggestions. After she brought the nasty veggie combo I asked for hot sauce since the food had absolutely no spice and I have eaten at many Ethiopian restaurants where i have eaten spicy lentil dishes, she replied " I don't like to do that" walked off with an attitude I still said thank you after she brought it and she just mumbled... I will never come here even if it was the last restaurant on earth. As an African I'm so hurt by the terrible service and food a bad representation of Ethiopia. I WILL MAKE SURE I TWEET AND TEXT EVERYONE I KNOW TO NEVER COME HERE.
author: Zeina C.

description:
It's not awful food, but just rather greasy.  The food (especially the combo platters) are an unbeatable value.  The injera (Ethiopian flat bread) is pretty good and not too heavy.  I found the vegetarian dishes to be tastier than the meat dishes.

Service is pretty poor, especially when the restaurant is near empty.  They have 'red' and 'white' wine on the menu, but must use industrial wine since they didn't know the varietal even after checking the bottle.  The tej 'honeywine' is an interesting drink, and resembles a slightly brandied sweet white wine.
author: Jeff A.

description:
OH why can't I control myself here. Seriously. The veggie combo is great. Yet when we go, we have to get veggie combo x number of us PLUS 2 or so meat dishes. Yup, dinner for 3 has FIVE entrees.
Sometimes we don't finish it all. but sadly, most times we do. It's really good. When you eat this much your fingers get dried out. It even tastes good with honey wine. (and it's the only way honey wine really tastes good).
One of the few places in SF that sells pitchers of beer. (alright, or one of the few places that I remember that does).
author: Margie L.

description:
cheap and delicious, the perfect combo. pretty boring atmosphere, but who cares. the food is great. Originally having Ethiopian food in Ethiopia, I was worried that the American version wouldn't compare. But, Axum cafe does a pretty good job.

We ordered the vegetarian for 2 plus a side meat dish and a bottle of the honey wine. its a lot of food, the 'for 2' can feed 3 easily.  has become my go to place whenever I crave Ethiopian. 

I recommend getting a sampler, the vegetarian is traditional in Ethiopia. it gives u chance to try a nice variety of things. And please people, wash your hands first! theres no eating utensils involved.
author: Carlynn A.

description:
I debated between 3 and 4 stars, because I realized that I wanted to like this place more than I did because I LOVE Ethiopian food and it's right by my house!  But it's just not as good as Addis in Oakland.  So I have to be honest and say 3 stars.

Decor is minimalist, but they keep the lighting low, so it feels cozy.  The Injera is pretty decent, though a little bland, portion sizes are generous, the price is right (though slightly less generous and slightly more expensive than comparable places in the East Bay, effing San Francisco!)  The spices are kind of bland, too, and it's all good but not wow or packed with flavor.

If you're not already close by and would need to make a trek to get here, you might as well hop on the BART to the East Bay and get some truly epic Ethiopian food over there.  But if you're in the area and looking for a good value and something yummy, then definitely go here!  I'll be back because it's close and when I'm craving Ethiopian it will at least hit the spot.   

All in all, good and satisfying but underwhelming if you really love Ethiopian food.

One thing I'll add is that in contrast to other people, I thought the service was fine.  They were packed on a Thursday night when I was there, but they were really accommodating.  I love friendly service and getting (figurative) hand jobs from servers at nice restaurants as much as the next guy, but I think friendly can also mean trying to make everything work for all your customers and they are definitely fine in that regard.  So they don't smile at you all the time.  Don't hold it against them, just get some real friends or something.
author: Ashley B.

description:
For my second time experiencing Ethiopian food, it was pretty good. Well given the fact that the first time it was like 15 years ago and we were appeasing our drink (or is that drunk) induced appetites!

So, I am definitely a fan of the delicious food
a fan of using hands and the crepes rather than utencils
a so-so fan of the honey wine
and even a fan of the semi- bitchy (or perhaps indifferent is a better description) waitress (she let us stay until absolute closing when everyoneone else was gone)
author: Vanessa J.

description:
Me: Vegetarian
Boyfriend: Eats meat

I order the vegetarian platter. He orders the chicken something.
The platter come out with chicken dumped on top. 
Waiter doesn't care.

Me: Never going there again
Boyfriend: Belives the place is a money laundering scheme and the "restaurant" and "food" parts are after thoughts.
author: Rory V.

description:
Mmmm.

Really great veggie variety taster platters- lentils, carrots, potatoes, greens- filling and flavorful.  It's a good choice fabulous for groups, as everyone gets a little bit of everything.  You eat with your hands, which, again, is fun for groups and parties.  Don't forget the ginger beer.  Really solid, cheap food.  I used to live quite close, and I went here once a month at least.
author: Christy T.

description: It's good but not great, cheap and satisfying and the folks are friendly.  Plus draft beer yay!
author: Julienne G.

description: I love this homey cute and  family-run restaurant. Th best part is the beef tibsie, vegetarian combo (mushrooms, lentils, chickpeas). The prices are fair and I am never disappointed. It's actually got spice without burning your tongue or anything. Good beer selection. A good gathering place for groups too. I highly recommend it.
author: Sari S.

description:
Literally across the street from a favorite hangout of mine, we decided to finally try Ethiopian food.  The place is charming in a dive-ish sort of way, the service terrific, and the food outstanding, and a great value.
We ordered the veggie combo and were met with tasty mushy treats and a salad.  I think the lentils were my favorite, oh, and the alicha, so yum.  The chickpeas I think were a little hotter than I expected and maybe would have liked, but overall a savory meal.
We were thirsty, and like I said, some things were kinda spicey, so we drank a lot of water, and our cups were never empty.
Loved it.  There was a group having their book club meeting up front, and I would say this is a perfect place for any group to come, or for a date like I did.
Way to go Axum, WAY TO GO.
author: kerry a.

description:
It's much more fun here (or at any Ethiopian restaurant) if you have a group of people - they heap all the food on a large platter and everyone just goes at it, picking and choosing from all the bounty, scooping up food with their spongy injera bread. The whole experience encourages conversation and just feels like what "family style" is supposed to be.

At any rate I've only been to two other Ethiopian restaurants in the Bay Area and I'd say Axum is tied for first in my mind with Zeni in San Jose. The tibsie lamb here is particularly delicious. I found the Tej wine to be really sweet and I had to take my time to finish it. 

Overall a great place for good food and bonding with friends.
author: Annee T.

description:
The bad news: Service can be extremely brusque, at least until it's time to pay the bill when it's all smiles and niceties. Also, most of the meat dishes taste like they were plucked from a rusty can of Dennison's Chili. In fact, the last time I went camping and ate chili out of a can pitched in the campfire, I thought of Axum.


 The good news: Axum elevates itself to 4 stars with the oft-mentioned vegetarian platter. Dirt cheap, plentiful, and oh-so-tasty.


 I'm still not a total fan of the injara bread, but I can overlook it when I'm using it to plow into the wide assortment of veggie delights piled on top of it. Be careful, though - since you're sharing the plate, you could get very competitive with your eating partners for every last morsel and wind up in a brawl. Or eat their fingers.


 So much for going vegetarian
author: Omid T.

description:
It's a dingy little place that's drafty inside but once you are there expect pleasant personal service and decent food.

It's not gourmet by a long stretch but tasty in a way that makes me wonder why I don't eat Ethopian more often.
author: Sean S.

description:
I went to Axum for the first time last night with friends. I have tried Ethiopian cusine at Red Sea in San Jose and Red Sea in Ypsilanti, MI, but have not eaten Ethiopian food for a while now. Since my friends are vegetarian, we ordered the vegetarian sampler and some Tej. 

The injera are more sour than I recall from my previous ethiopian meal. While it is not unpleasant, it did add another element to the meal which I did not enjoy. It was also thinner than what I had recall, but actually prefer a thinner injera.

The sampler came with a green salad, topped with traditional Ethiopian dressing that taste surprisingly like pesto, a mushroom dish, a chickpea dish, a lentil dish and a cabbage/potato dish.

The mushroom dish was by far my favorite. The mushrooms are meaty, and seasoned just right. The chickpea and lentil dishes are pureed and quite mild in taste and spices. I personally would prefer more agressive spicing on these 2 dishes. The cabbage/potato dish is also fairly mild, but the carrots are especially tasty after the simmering. I prefer my potatoes and carrots cooked a little longer, but that may not be the Ethiopian style.

None of the items had a distinctive taste that would strongly suggest the food is of Ethiopian origins. I also recall the food is more spicy in the previous Ethiopian restaurants where I had dined.

Tej, as usual, is quite mild and enjoyable with the cusine. 

Overall, a rather enjoyable meal, but not outstanding in a divey joint.
author: hsiao c.

description:
This place has been understaffed every time I've been there which is a bummer, but they've always been good answering questions and coming around within a decent amount of time.  

It's not perfect but it has a decent atmosphere and the food is good.
author: daniel m.

description:
Axum is a really great place to have in the neighborhood.  The service is friendly, the food is delicious and the portions are generous.  Although I usually take it to go, I find the simple decor to be pretty fun - it's got all these tourism ministry posters, and the lamp shades cast the place in a sort of yellow glow that feels very warm.

I don't care much for the salad-type accompaniments to the meal, a little bland and mushy, but the meat and veggie entrees are great.  I've had about 1/2 the menu; if you're in the mood for seafood the tibsie shrimp is delicious, and if not the beef and chicken varieties are also good.

Although I do it quite often (I live next door), take-out from Axum loses a little something.  Something about the way everything is laid out doesn't translate so well.  Just be aware.
author: Oliver N.

description:
Dumb-dumb hostess lip
Cheap beer, lots of spices here
Wash your hands first
author: HaikuReview S.

description: Absolutely love this place.  Great vegetarian options!
author: Kasie V.

description:
Axum is still my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the neighborhood. It is family owned and has been in the neighborhood for years. Here are some of my favorites

-The chickpeas
-The lentils
-the lamb
-the honey wine
-the salad dressing (so good!)

It is inexpensive and great for vegetarians. I can spend $20 and have food for 2 days.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Went here last night. 

Bad news first: the service was pretty bad: slow and forgetful, but they were nice. 

Good news: a veggie plate with all 5 veggie dishes (enough for two people) was $15. pretty good. 

Not my favorite ethiopian food in the city but still pretty tasty and not overpriced.
author: Geryon R.

description:
Given the location of this restaurant, it's very affordable for a little treat for my taste buds. 

Any vegan would love this place. I find myself savoring the food there time after time. I've had Ethiopian food before, but this is my first all-vegetarian Ethiopian restaurant. Don't let the less-than-decorated exterior of the cafe fool you, it is no ordinary place. The authenticity of the food flavor will win our heart over. 

As for the service, I believe it is run by the owners so their service is not the usual "Hi How are you doing" Southern comfort attitude. 

Overall, I'd say if you are in the Haight-Ashbury Area, Axum is a nice alternative for a healthy, spicy, exotic cuisine.
author: Jack C.

description:
My standard go-to for dinner (partly b/c it's great, partly b/c its walking distance)

Excellent flavors - especially for the veggie items.

Veggie combo or platters are the way to go for quick service and yummy food.  The meat dishes are totally passable but they take a long time to make it to your table.
author: Sarah L.

description:
A solid, quality place, with the fifth star for value.  

I like the veggie combo, even though I'm not vegetarian, but a nice alternative to the rest of the diet I've eaten during the week.  I've also had some of the chicken and lamb dishes here, wonderful.  

They also make a great latte and have quality beers on tap.  It attracts unpretentious customers, which adds to the nice vibe here (an opulent remodel might hurt this place).   It has a nice family feel.  I think only four different people served me during the past few years.  These sort of places are treasures in SF.
author: Jim M.

description: I LOVE axum! The owners treat you like family and the food is consistently good. The place is clean! i LOVE it!
author: Melorra G.

description:
My first experience eating Ethiopian food was not a pleasant one. I was already having trouble distinguishing the pureed food assortments when Jocie commented on the striking similarity of injera to that of wet, soggy ace bandages. After hearing that, I could no longer eat with my hands, scooping the food. When I asked for silverware, the waitress looked at me like a deer in headlights. 

Friday evening rolls around; that means dining club. It's Jen's turn to pick the place. Becky, Rebecca and I wait all day long in anticipation to figure out what we'll be having from that evenings' menu.  Finally, its decided we're going to Axum Cafe. My very first though, "Ace Bandages". Needless to say, anticipation turned to anguish.    When I first walked in, the set up reminded me of a few cafes/restaurants I've been to in the Abacos. The barred windows and door hanging on by probably some rope,  Axum is a seat yourself, chill kind of environment.  The food was better and they carry silverware; ok, maybe only forks.
author: Casie C.

description:
I've went quite some time ago, and wasn't bothered with the fact I had to grub hands-on. Sh******t, gettin' back to my roots like my moms did up in the PI. A kid at heart so you know I had a good time, less the mess. I am a fan of sour/bitter flavors, and that it was, the chicken I got was excellent. The folks serving us were all smiles.

It gets pretty crowded when late, so I you have a group go early evening.
author: riz l.

description:
I used to love Axum, it was my favorite Ethiopian in the city. I think I could have spent hours eating their veggie combo platter. It was cheap and delicious, which made the slow service more than tolerable. However, my last three visits to Axum have proven a great disappointment to me. The food has been flavorless (and that's all veggie entrees), the lentils runny, and what used to be a lovely homemade basily-minty salad dressing has been replaced with something that can best be described as wishbone-wannabe.

The other thing is that it seems the entire staff has changed. For as long as I've been going to Axum (which is about 10 years -- I believe I first ate there in 1997!), the staff has been the same. This year (2007), I haven't seen those familiar faces, so I wonder if the "good" staff moved to the other location or just sold the business.
author: Carla B.

description:
We had the veggie platter... fantastic!  They also have Anchor Steam and Fat Tire on tap - two of my favorites... great location and interior and hours.

Still the winner for me is the place in Berkeley... the Blue Nile.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Of the Ethiopian places I've been in San Francisco (four of them - on Geary, Divisidero, Valencia and here), this is my favorite.

The food here is not only ample (most Ethiopian/Eritrean places are), it's authentic. Or at least compared to the food I've had in the Horn of Africa. The spices are well proportioned, its not TOO greasy, and generally it's yummy.

I know the Ethiopian is good when I get to the too-full feeling, and still want to eat just a little bit more. Ahhh... I miss Hebesha!
author: Jen B.

description:
I agree with many fellow yelpers- just because it's veggie shouldn't mean it's bland.  The food was warm and plentiful, but one pile of colored mush pretty much tasted the same as the next.  The service was really good, though.

On another note, the honey wine tasted remarkably like manishevitz.  Which is to say, it sucks.
author: Mark G.

description:
I love eating with my hands, so three stars for letting me be the hungry piggy who can't be bothered with a fork. 

three stars also for the food. . . which was kinda good but was the color of baby poo.  you eat with your eyes first right?  

so maybe it wasn't the best idea to order the raw beef (which was good but i was weirded out because i kept reminding myself it was raw beef).   the spinach and the mushroom appetizers were pretty good, but again, the greenish brown colors laying on an open flat pancake reminds me of a diaper (you know, like when you open a burrito from taco bell....)   

the chickpea puree was good but i probably won't go back even though the service was good.  i even had leftovers but decided not to take it.  i mean if it looks like baby poo when it's fresh, it's not going to be appetizing a day later.
author: regina k.

description:
The food is OK. The service is terrible. The guy who run it is a good host, but if you go in when the lady is running it, it is a major annoyance. 

She dictates what one should order, charges extra for dough bread, refuses to give spoons (for children) and tried to squeeze 5 adults and two children into a 4 table setting. 

There are plenty of other Ethiopian restaurants in town. I will avoid this one.
author: Samurai Z.

description:
My main memory of Axum is the super speedy service: we walked in, were shown a table, given menus, ordered, got the drinks, got the food (veggie platter for 2), all in less than 5 minutes, max. I didn't exactly feel rushed, and the service was pleasant though not exactly friendly, but I dunno, I guess I like it if a restaurant at least pretends that it's preparing the food fresh for you by letting you wait a bit...I also would have liked if they'd given wipes or wet towels or something to wash your hands with before the meal like some places do, considering that you eat the food with your hands off of a communal plate. But, it's a cheap restaurant, so whatever. There's a bathroom, it's good enough.

The injera was quite nice, not too pungent (maybe it's toned down for a Western palate, but that's how I like it). The potato dish was fine as well, similar to an Indian curry. The other vegetable dishes were good and spiced nicely, but on a whole a bit too oily and wet for my taste--less of the oily sauce would be healthier, fresher tasting, and not leave me this weighed down, heavy, slightly sick of Ethiopian food feeling. The worst was the spinach dish: the spinach was canned, horribly overcooked, and had a bit of an off flavor. I've been to a few African restaurants recently, and they all seem to have a fresh-spinach-phobia, but Axum's spinach....damnnn...even popeye wouldn't eat that stuff. If you order the veggie platter, I'd recommend asking to substitute the spinach with something else (unless you want to have a greenish-black blob taking up valuable injera space).

Despite those complaints, I did enjoy the experience and the food, and I'll be back. This would be a great place to take people who haven't had Ethiopian before; the flavors aren't as overpowering as at some Ethiopian places I've been to.
author: Sarah J.

description:
A long time ago, i was conversing with my mom about the pleasures of eating raw meat.  I described to her how tastey a big pile of raw meat Ethopian style could be.  And last week I was hoping to share that experience with my mom, but though a pile o' meat we did eat, it had been exposed to some heat, despite my twice stating that I wanted it to be a raw treat.  Ok, so maybe I should be thankful that someone was looking out for me and decided their meat was not fit for serving raw, and since I didn't spent any night wretching or curled up in pain, sweating, dizzy (hmmm, i'm having flaskbacks of Thailand), I can say I wanted that stuff raw.

To be fair, the food at Axum was good.  After finishing my injera, I proceeded to eat the piece that our dishes had been spread out on, that soaked up their spicey yummy dishes.  Unfortunately I've been spoiled.  I lived in DC for quite a while, and having the largest Ethopian population outside of Ethopia, they also have tons of great Ethopian food.  I've had so much that I've eaten until excruciating pain.  At Axum, my belly merely hurt after all was said and done.

Anyone know where I can get some good raw kitfo?
author: Adrian L.

description:
I was really excited to go here. I have heard (not from you picky Yelpers, but from co-workers and friends) and they raved about how cheap it is, and how yummy the food was. 

Me and my two friends ordered the veggie combo and a REALLY spicy (even though I asked for a milder chicken dish...I cant even imagine how spicy the SPICY one is!). The veggie combo resembled baby food and had little flavor and no texture (I know its a puree, but it was bland and too smooth!) The chicken chunks were good, but the sauce it was slathered in was CRAZY spicy and very hot (as in temperature, I burned the top of my mouth)
The spongy bread was a little too sour for my taste, but when slathered in purees, that sour flavor disappeared. 
My favorite part of the meal was the pitcher of Anchor Steam I shared with my favorite friends.

Bummer...I had such high hopes for this place.


Also, we couldnt split our bills using credit cards. So, my bf had to walk down the street to an overpriced bar atm to get cash. that was lame.

I wont be back.
author: Keila E.

description:
Why are you not at Club Waziema?

It is not that Axum is that bad, it just is not that good.

Place is a little dirty and the service is, well, predictably bad.
author: Kiki I.

description:
When it comes to heights and dogs -- especially big ones -- I would say it is so, but never am I fearful of food. The greater the exoticism, the greater the adventure. Although one could argue that Ethiopian can no longer claim its rarity and mystique in pretentious San Francisco. Why, there's also another one just a few blocks up on the Upper Haight, and surely the Mission is replete with them. However, my much needed stop to Safeway assured my decision to dine at Axum Cafe.

My friend and I haven't had Ethiopian food and was most curious. I must admit, lacking prior knowledge, I was intimidated; ever nervous of any social function wherein I might, out of ignorance, commit a breach of manners. A self-consciousness most people (left-leaning, Liberal, wannabe-"creative"-types) daren't admit to, but I theorize to be a fundamental social truth. We are hierarchical animals. And although careless of its imposition on ourselves, expect a fair amount of etiquette on others -- for the sake of our appetite! Observing others' tables stealthily, I got a sense of how one lays the table where Ethiopian is served, and quite blindly, we ordered away!

I was in for quite a delicious surprise! The food was fantastic! I had the Tibsie Fish, and it was absolutely scrumptious! With my indiscriminate and erudite taste-buds, I wouldn't say that the flavors were all that foreign, but that injera was just absolutely amazing.

The ambiance too made quite a modest impression. Of course one could expect motherland relics and decorations, even when it borders on the tacky, but the feel of the place was comfortable, casual and serene. People came as they are, and I've noticed, left exquisitely satiated. 

Axum Cafe definitely deserves several more visits to fully take in its concept. But what with my fantastic first impression, my exuberance cannot be held still. I will definitely frequent -- and highly recommend -- this place. And I am more than enthusiastic to sample other Ethiopian restaurants in the city.
author: Rho-p O.

description: I really enjoyed this place, the food is delicious. I shared the vegetarian platter with a couple of friends and it was very tasty.
author: Nina K.

description:
No school like the old school.
This place will always be one of my favorite San Francisco restaurants because, well, Axum just rocks! Cheap, tasty, and utensils to the wind. 
A must-go for people who have not yet had Ethiopian food. Vegetarian friendly.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
I've never had ethiopian food before and so happy to find one across from my apt! Though I only been there once, but I could see myself coming back soon!

We had the vegetarian platter and it was yummy! I would definitely try the meat entree the next time I'm going. 

The service was so so. The waitress, who's also the owner I believe, wasn't particularly friendly and the cleanliness of this place was doubting. I was waiting for a bus in front of this restaurant and I could see some dead bugs under the windows. Maybe now after they renovated it would be different.
author: Perry S.

description:
I dont know much about ethiopian food but this place was deeelish!
I do not however recommend the mushroom dish.
author: S M.

description:
Decent Ethiopian Food. In my hood. Three stars.

Not as good as Cafe Eritrea D'afrique in Oaktown or Gojo in San Jose (and no meat sampler is a little disappointing) but it's worth an occasional visit when I get the hankering.
author: Joe D.

description:
This was my first Ethiopian experience.  I was somewhat disappointed.  Service was not friendly.  It was a party of 3, and we ordered 3 items on the menu--chicken, beef, and spinach.  I simply wasn't a fan of the beef dish.  Not a fan of the flavor and it was also too salty for my taste.  The chicken dish was good, but looking at the puddle of grease running into the center of the big communal dish was pretty disturbing.  The spinach just tasted like spinach.  Not much to it.  I don't like the pancake-type bread.  Too sour for me and doesn't compliment the food in my opinion.  I'm not sure if all Ethiopian bread tastes like that at all restaurants.  Either way, I would like to try Ethiopian again somewhere else.  I would pay a little more for better food.  I have a feeling I would really like it if I found the right spot.  And I question the establishment's cleanliness.

Update:  Returned to Axum and tried the Tibsie Beef.  It was really tough.  It was still just a 2-star experience.
author: Kandi K.

description:
A friend of mine were scrambling around the MUNI throughout the city looking for a good Ethiopian restaurant... from the mission district through Haight-Ashbury. Everything seemed to be closed, so we decided to head to a friends house, and to our astonishment was Axum 50 ft away from our friends house.
Atmosphere: Was here for the dinner, dim lighting with families and couples on intimate-looking dates. Quiet and comfortable with a TV behind the bar. As i recall, the restaurant was dimly lit, reminding me of an old Italian restaurant (which, makes me laugh because Ethiopia was one of the few African nations to resist colonialism by kicking Mussolini out). ANYWHO... nice, quite and cozy.
Service: seemed to be a slow night (monday) one server, very nice, friendly, efficient.
food: AMAZING. love love love the veggie combo... shared it with a friend, and we were throughly satisfied by the time the injera had vanished! If you havent tried Tej (honey wine) i do recommend it. As a vegetarian, im not really a fan, but can imagine it pairing better with heavier meat dishes!
author: Lindsay S.

description: this is good ethiopian. the veggie combo is vegan and gluten-free. friendly staff. pleasant, no-frills dining room. writing this review is making me hungry for axum :)...
author: joey e.

description: Love the food, the laid back atmosphere, and friendly smiling staff! It is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco! I go at least a few times a month! Try the veggie sampler for two and the lamb! YUM! Lots of good beer on tap! :)
author: Karin Z.

description: SF's affordable, diverse ethnic food options are staggering.  Axum Cafe is a family run Ethiopian restaurant that was crowded with locals and tourists the night we went.  I sipped honey wine with my vegetarian combo platter-- mountains of lentils, chickpeas, and mixed vegetables atop spongey injera.  The service is attentive and polite, and at $9 for the platter, this is a huge bargain.
author: L C.

description:
I hadn't eaten Ethiopian food before and always wanted to give it a shot.  I went with friends based on recommendations from Yelp.

Overall, I thought the food was pretty good.  We had a vegetarian platter with a chicken dish as well.  The server was nice and helpful.

I didn't like the atmosphere as much.  The bathroom was clean.  However, it would've been a nice touch to offer serviettes or some other hand-cleaning product to patrons before they ate (as you eat it with your hands).

I would go back.
author: Jonathan C.

description: It was my first time trying Ethiopian food and it was delicious.  I went there with my sister and 2 old friends and the shared the vegetarian platter for 4 and added the fish to it. All the veggies were good with great spices and flavor.  The fish was amazing.  The service was great...very patient considering that 2 of us sat there for a half hour waiting for the other 2 people in our party.  The price was pretty cheap for the platter for us to share.  I definately cannot wait to go back and eat there again.
author: Bianca G.

description:
I went here for my birthday dinner. yes, my birthday dinner. I wanted to barf. No offense to Ethiopian food but maybe this wasnt the best place. I wanted pizza and instead I got some mashed up veggies and meat and what i thought was going to be the best part of the meal, the little scooping bread, was weird tasting. I wanted to barf mainly because it smelled so weird in the restaurant which looked like I was in some war country. They are in dire need of some redecorating/cleaning. 
There were no Ethiopian people in there besides maybe the owners. Instead it was full of cultural hipsters. The types that have been to Thailand to seek further life meaning and find themselves. 
They had beer which was the best thing on the menu.
author: andree t.

description:
I am a big fan of ethnic foods and this place is not exception.  The food and service are great.  For a social outing or a 3rd date(on a budget) where you want to just have fun and a good conversation....  I say to go Axum

12/31/09  It is 5 Stars, The Veggie Combo with the Chickpeas, Lentils, and Mushrooms and nothing else!  So Very Good!
author: Austin S.

description:
I love their fish ( and I never order fish normally) and their honey wine.
their fish is so good that I can eat my fingers with it. Vegetarian dishes are great too. its good for a neighborhood restaurant but not the best location for a date.
author: Lane B.

description: Since Massawa closed we have been on the hunt for a replacement. I now realize just how special and tasty they were. Axum was NOT Massawa. I've never had such Flavorless Ethiopian food. It must be paired down in flavor for what they think Americans want. The  chicken had no spice  and was full of gristle . No yogurt  on the platter. We talked about sending a gift certificate to them for the place out on Geary or one of the great Ethiopian spots in DC..because these guys need to step up their game. Two stars because getting a window seat was easy..the place was empty. Service was horrible, had to wait for her to finish talking w/ the regulars to get order placed, for food to come and for drinks. Will not be returning.
author: Belle A.

description:
I had diner there yesterday with 5 other friends. Even if the place is not appealing at all, we decided to try Ethiopian food for the first time. It was not good at all, WAY too spicy and I was sick right after the diner. I hope you have a solid stomach if you plan to eat there!

Minus one star for the un-welcoming service and for the fact that they tried to sell us 2 platters for 3 people which was more expensive than the platter for 6.

Minus TEN stars for the fact that I saw the waitress going outside the restaurant with our 2 credit cards, and for the fact that the restaurant charged me $80 AND $40 instead of just $40 which was half of the bill to credit on each credit card. I call that FRAUD, and It's not the first time that happens in this restaurant: http://local.yahoo.com/profile?target=abAEaU3CPWO.qSaI7ZAdxsVMAAJD1WUmy

Just don't go there, it's not even worth the cheap prices of the menu!
author: Matt T.

description: Really delicious food, but the service was lacking; however, it was lower-Haight artwalk night, so no doubt, the 1 gentleman and 1 water-guy, were slammed.  The platter for 3 was more than enough for 3 - probably 4 - 5 would clean the heaping disc of deliciousness.  Love the spinach, mushroom, 2 possibly-lentil/chickpea mushes and the lamb.  Be warned - the lamb is spicier than a little bit spicy.  It's hottie-hot like Lindsey Lohan disrobing before incarceration.  Everything was fresh and non-greasy and the injera spongebread is like a snack-poncho friend - delicious.  We quietly brought our own beer and they were cool with it.  $32 fed 3 people with tons to spare.
author: T L.

description:
I'll start with the good - prices were excellent, and the food pretty good. Not the best ethiopian in the city, but holds it's own.

Now the reason why it gets two stars. The service was hands down the worst I've ever had in San Francisco. The waitress was terrible. It started when I asked for a recommendation between two dishes, and she tried to push a combo sampler. After repeatedly saying no, I finally picked one to make her stop. Our water arrived with no ice. And then the waiting. And more waiting. And more waiting, as people who came in after us got served, and all we did was wait. Finally, 20min later, the food emerged, which she served with minimal eye contact, no apologies, and practically was making a dash away from the table before setting the food down. We had to get up to get water refills, and had to seek out our check as well. Only time in my life I've felt 100% OK with leaving zero tip.

The restaurant was fairly full for a Labor Day, perhaps others have had better experiences. Judging from other reviews, it doesn't sound like this is a rare occurrence.
author: Jason B.

description:
Me Like!

The place is around the corner from where I live and so I finally hit the place up. We got the veggi sampler for 3 and it was just the right amount of food and tasty goodness for dinner. If you a germ freak, then you'll proly not want to stop by, being that you'll have to eat with your hands. Pretty cool place, good down to earth atmosphere, and the Meta Lager Ethiopian beer is damn good, try it!
author: Alex P.

description:
Wow, I had a great dinner here last night. Our food came out very fast for how crowded the restaurant was. The veggie combo platter for three is definitely big enough for four. The shrimp was also very good. 
atmosphere: quaint, I enjoyed the fringe lamps over every table
food: hot and fresh
service: speedy- I will say I did not completely understand our waiter, but he took great care of us. Just smile and nod
price: very reasonable
overall: it was fantastic and will be going back next week
author: A D.

description:
My stomach is turning writing this review, feeling pains from a not so great meal and rude service.
We were the only people there at 7pm on a Tuesday night, and the person I was with said he thought we'd probably get served warmed up food from earlier in the day. He was half right. The food was from earlier in the day but not quite warmed up.
The waitress was surly and acted like she didn't want us to be there..
author: Bart A.

description: I've been here once with my boyfriend and he isn't really a fan of Ethiopian food, but he really liked Axum. The food is really delicious but the atmosphere leaves something to be desired. Actually come to think of it, all Ethiopian places seem to struggle with interior decorating. Still, the interior is very sparse and has almost a cafeteria like feel to it. It's very casual dinning.
author: jen w.

description:
Very good selection of Ethiopian food - the veggie combo, along with chicken drumsticks were an excellent combination.

Would have been 5 star had the waitress been a little happier and more patient.
author: Ron B.

description: For San Francisco this is about as authentic as you are going to find around here! Great injera ba wot & usually somewhat busy because it is good.  Only drawback is that they charge you for extra injera. (take it from the guy that grew up in Ethiopia).
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I must start by saying this was my first experience with Ethiopian food, and was sadly let down.  Maybe Ethiopian is not for me, but I think this was just sub-standard Ethiopian food.  
I ordered the Vegetarian Sampler for $9 which consisted of my choice of three "dishes" a small salad and injera bread.  The salad had a wonderful dressing but everything else was quite bland.  Everything tasted like the main ingredient and nothing more.  The bread also had a very sour flavor that took some getting used to and didn't really add to the flavor of the foods, but rather took the spotlight due to the lack of other flavors.  
I really wanted to like this place.   My waiter was a very young boy, probably the owners' son, who, by the way, seemed almost surprise when I told him of my satisfaction with the food.  There was a family feel to the place and I was happy to be supporting their business, but am sorry to say I will not be continuing my support.  I will however give Ethiopian food another try.
author: Dan L.

description: Love this place! Not high on ambiance, but the best Ethiopian food I have had. Excellent tibsie chicken, tibsie lamb, and vegetarian platter combo (i.e. lentils, spinach, chickpeas).
author: Michelle P.

description: So tonight we spent about $70 on four (different) people and enjoyed every moment. We got about six different dishes and they all were served on one big plate. We also received yummy sponge bread as utensils. The meal was delicious and we all felt happy and content afterward. Yum!
author: Mitsi M.

description: I remember eating here and having such a great time! I loved eating the food and eating with your hands.  Great experience. I definitely want to go back! Definitely a place if you want to try something new and exciting!
author: Mel P.

description:
As far as I can tell, Axum represents the best of what's around for Ethiopian food in SF.  Personally I am a devotee of Merkato in LA and poor Axum can't hold a candle in terms of flavor, price or atmosphere... but it's still very good (BTW, my boyfriend maintains that I'm a huge Ethiopian food snob and Axum is great, no qualifiers).  Anyway, because I miss Merkato so much we've been on a quest to find good Ethiopian food in San Francisco and Axum is the top contender right now.  The restaurant is small but clean and friendly and the service is pleasant and competent (though sometimes be a bit slow due to being overwhelmed).  Our favorite dishes are the tsebi he derho (chicken drumsticks in sauce), which tastes a bit like what I've always associated with yedoro wat, but a little spicier and tomato-y and no eggs, and alicha ater (pureed chickpeas).  We really did not enjoy the collards or regular alicha (mostly cauliflower), but this is probably because we are little kids who won't eat our veggies at heart.  The injera is not as sour and spongy as it should be and I don't think it's made with tef (wrong color), but it's still quite good.  Sadly, they do not have Ethiopian tea, but they do have hot apple cider which makes a decent substitute.  The portions are generous and the prices are great for San Francisco.   Overall, a great place and we've become very fond of it.

PS.  Axum can get a little cold (no carpet, lots of windows, jerks leave the door open) so bring a sweater!
author: Marie K.

description: Had dinner here last night. I had the vegetarian combo with greens,lentil and mixed vegetables and Harar Beer that was tasty. It was very authentic and close to what my grandmother would make. Another big plus ***It's open until 10:30pm***
author: Teddy d.

description: Damn, so tasty. I had seen this place a million times, but never made the effort to go in, but now I am sooo glad that I did. A block from my house and always satisfys. Flavor that I just crave sometimes. Atmosphere is better for couples or groups than dining alone, so I have to always suggest it when people are visiting.
author: Tom H.

description: Amazing ethiopian food with friendly staff and reasonable prices. When I lived in the neighborhood I came twice a week and now I drive up from Palo Alto to get my fix. I highly recommend the tumtumo in particular!
