author: Kate F.

description: Great food and very affordable. We got the Veggie Platter for Two, it cost $18 and filled us both up. It's a mom and pop establishment and that's who serves you. It can get very busy, so be patient when you are trying to order, get refills or get your check. Try to go early so that you can get a table without waiting. It's best to go in groups of 4 or less.
author: Rex D.

description: Good for groups, as long as no one's picky - nice big plates of food and not much waiting.  The environment has kind of dark lighting, so a great place to bring an ugly date.  I recommend the honey wine.
author: Jennifer M.

description: I definitely like getting messy, but the food was just OK.  And what really threw me off was the pancake stuff you are supposed to grab and eat your food with.  I didn't like it at all.  It had this tangy taste kind of like vinegar.  It was really overpowering.  I'm not sure if they just messed it up that day or if it was actually supposed to taste like that.  I would go back, but maybe ask for different bread.  Or a fork.
author: Starla D.

description: Hot spicy food. I tried one chicken, and one fish dish, and they were delicious. You'll get used to eating with your hands quickly. I asked for a spoon to serve the food, but that's a no-no, and the waitress didn't even stop to consider it.
author: Ed R.

description: I take my second dates to Axum.  Here's why.  For starters, as you can see by other reviews, Axum is one of, if not the best, Ethiopian restaurants in town.  It's also a great value--get an amazing meal for two, with beers for under $20.  It is not fancy, and it doesn't try.  It is a hole-in-the-wall with non-descript art and minimalist furniture.  Let's face it, it is grungy, and fabulously unpretentious.  I can love any man that loves Axum.
author: Katie S.

description: I can't quite put a finger on it, but I really enjoy eating here. Simple, cheap food, served on linoleum tables, that's never bland. Engaging to eat, and interesting drinks like honey wine.
author: Maia B.

description:
ok they were *not* kidding when they told us to use a smaller table so that we could reach our food.  this place does not have utensils.  not even those meant for serving.  so if you plan on eating with a large group.... get ready to pardon each others' reach over and over and over again.

i think the food was decent, and i suppose if you like eating with your hands knock yerself out!
author: lulu p.

description: For inexpensive ethiopian food this place is the best! I love it...my friend and I shared the veggie combo platter for two, which costs $14, and we were both full and happy...
author: Amanda D.

description:
it was a lot better 10 years ago.. but still good
the wait was a bit long... 45 min.

the atmosphere was kind and mellow
the portions were decent

the staff friendly

the food was tasty.. but i dont know what it was..something was different. didnt feel "special" anymore..
author: tanner r.

description: Yum!  So many new flavors, sour and spicy!  Authentic, delicious, cheap!  Very filling!
author: Liz Y.

description: So damn good.  Finger licking good even.  This is the best Ethiopean place I've found in the city.  Have a plate full of goodness on top of unleavened bread with a cup of hot cider.  Great place to go for first timers.
author: Cyan C.

description:
i didn't care much for their injera bread.  it tasted really sour and it had an odd after taste.  

we ordered the platter for 4 people and everything was fine, but there wasn't much of a difference in the flavors of the foods.
author: Immer E.

description: Cheap and tasty food with nice service in an ambience-free space.
author: Annette K.

description: From the nekkid boobies on the wall to the kintishara, this place is all-around fantabulous. A veggie combo with a meat dish (Kitfo is fucking amazing!) does two people quite nicely.
author: Kelly M.

description: So let's recap, a plater for four including pockets of alicha ater, hamli, kintishara, and throw is some lamb cubes for $26?  And I can have a premium beverage for $3.50 while eating with my hands?  That's the deal of the century.  We took our good friend AFP (that's ass face patterson) to Axum with his lovely non-ass-face wife, and they denied his request for utensils...brilliant!  I saw the wave of concern run across his face, because with the AFP volume=quality equation, I think he was afraid that the hands would not prove to be sufficient shoveling tools.  It's the same logic he applies to chinese as he tosses aside the chopsticks and goes full-on fork.  It's embarrassing for all of us.  But I assure you, we all had plenty to eat (even AFP).  And did I mention it was only $26?
author: Julie B.

description:
We had dinner here on a weekend night.  A simple restaurant--they didn't have any of the woven basket type of tables (I keep forgetting to look up the word for these) at this place.

When we first walked in, we weren't sure if it was seat yourself or what, because no one greeted us.  So, there was an empty table, which we headed toward, & someone came over with menus & wiped down the table.  So, I'm still not sure if it's seat yourself or not.  
I had hot tea ('cuz I was kind of sick & thought it'd soothe my throat---no double dipping for me!).  One of my friends got the tej (honey wine).  I didn't try it because I didn't want to get anyone else sick, but they described it as like "cough syrup."  That might have helped me!

We got tibsie lamb (select cuts of tender lamb sauted with onions, jalapeno peppers, garlic, tomatoes, and authentic Ethiopian spices)---yummy sauce, tsebi he derho (marinated chicken drumsticks simmered in tomatoes, garlic, onions and traditional spicy Ethiopian butter)---relatively easy to peel the meat off the drumstick, but not falling off the drumstick, and zighine (tender cuts of select beef sliced into cubes; marinated and simmered in tomatoes, onions, and traditional spicy Ethiopian butter).  We originally wanted the veggie combo & had picked out hamli (spinach and jalapeno peppers simmered in onions, garlic and authentic Ethiopian spices), kintishara (mushrooms diced and simmered in tomatoes, onions, garlic and authentic Ethiopian spices), & tumtumo (lentil beans pured and simmered in onions, garlic and authentic Ethiopian spices) as our 3 choices, but then I think we confused the server, because then we decided we wanted 2 veggie combos to be sure we'd have enough food.  Instead, when the food all came out on the humongous injera lined platter, we they had given us the veggie platter, which consisted of alicha (potatoes, carrots, cabbage, jalapeno peppers, garlic stewed in our authentic Ethiopian spices), alicha ater (chickpea pured with onions and authentic Ethiopian spices)---kind of bland, hamli, tumtumo, and salad.   Of course we didn't notice until we'd eaten half of it & someone exclaimed, "where are the mushrooms?!"  That's when we figured it out.  Oh well.  It's all good.  So, I still have yet to try mushrooms at an Ethiopian place.  We each got a big circular piece of injera folded into quarters, & they brought one extra piece for us to share, which I don't think we finished, so we didn't even have to ask for more.  The injera was not quite as spongy as others I've had, but was still just as filling.

There was one group there in the middle of the room that was quite loud.  OK, actually, I think it was mostly one guy in the group who was very loud, but maybe he was drunk.  Anyway, one of my friends made a very loud comment about it, & I was making little volume knob turning motions with my hands, so we were a little obnoxious/obvious about it (but I was not really in the mood for loud), so they actually apologized to us about being loud when they were on their way out---that was a nice gesture on their part (they didn't sound like they were being sarcastic, & they could've totally ignored us).  And it did get significantly quieter after they left.

It ended up costing us about $15 each, so not bad for a filling dinner.  We still had room for dessert, though, & had been discussing where we wanted to go towards the end of our meal.

Located on the northeast corner of Haight & Pierce.  Parking wasn't too bad, but I think we lucked out after circling around a couple times...we parked a little over a block away.
author: Linda T.

description: Good food, great location. Comparisons with Waziema, my favorite Ethiopian place, are inevitable. Axum is cheaper but lacks the ambiance of Waziema. The injera is more sour, which I liked. The vegetarian combo was a lot oilier than at Waziema but still tasty. My only complaint besides the oil is that the chickpea portion was too liquidy to pick up with the injera and had to be dipped into.
author: Wendy C.

description: I will say I like this place plenny good.  It's not my FAVE RAVE - Assab, but it's also a LOT less expensive.  Everything was impeccably fresh, the place is IMMACULATELY CLEAN, and I agree with another reviewer that this might be a good place to pop your Ethiopian/Eritrean cherry to see how you feel about it.  The server was very attentive and I'll go back in a heartbeat.
author: Enzo L.

description:
what do you get when u put a bunch of stuff in a food processor?  completely unidentifiable and non-authentic Ethiopian food.

i've had better baby food.

oh yeah, don't forget to look at the door around the doorknob when u walk out of this place....quite filthy!  bring Purell.
author: Christine R.

description: I've been a loyal patron of Wazima on Divis since I discovered my love for Ethiopian food last year, but a recent visit to Axum Cafe has made me reconsider my dedication.  While I'm not sure the atmosphere is quite as divey I'd like (if I'm going to eat with my hands, I want the place to be dirty and dark), the food is of a similar quality.  Plus, some people might actually prefer that you can see your meal while you are eating it.
author: Katie S.

description: I've been here twice with friends, one of whom LOVES this place. I thought the food was really good, simply prepared, and the injera is fabulous (and they bring you extra!). However I prefer spicier food, which I've had at Ethiopian restaurants in Michigan. The service is outrageously fast and if you don't order booze, the prices are pretty reasonable. I would definitely come back here especially with groups as  hands-on, communal eating arrangement fun and friendly.
author: Adri M.

description: One of my favorite Ethiopian restaurants. Their kintishara is out of this world! Not very many people offer this hard-to-find dish.
author: Ray G.

description: I find it totally hot when a date shows me a new place that I haven't already experienced myself.  I was leery of Axum since the outside is pretty much covered by iron bars.  But P led me inside and I found a very warm and inviting place, full of pretty artwork and lamps.  We ordered beef, chicken, and mushrooms to eat with the injera, along with some beers.  The food was delicious but  Water + Beer + Injera = DANGEROUS!  I had to consciously stop eating before the expanding bread cut off my circulation.
author: Pelle Y.

description: This is a very simple restaurant. A hole in the wall, if you will. What it looks like on the outside does not at all represent the quality of the food, which is so flavorful  and if I was Ethiopian, it tastes like grandma's cooking. You can order multiple dishes but they put it all on one plate and you eat with your hands. So go with a clean person who washes their hands before sticking their paws in the food. Their Tibsie chicken is my favorite, and the lentil dish is a nice vegetarian compliment (it comes with any dish you order). They give you extra injera bread, which is a sour soft crepe and you eat the meat or veggies with the bread. Try the Ethiopian beer, it goes well with the spices.
author: S K.

description: This is true comfort food, and the family that runs the place is super-friendly. I just wish they had a door that automatically closed, because so many people just walk in and forget to close it, and the cold air rushes in.
author: Bronwyn X.

description: With Axum I wish yelp had half stars...That being said, I had to round up for the quality of their food, and would have liked to round down for the service.  We had a group of ten visit last week (tab was picked up by my visiting parents, you're welcome friends of mine), ordering for a large group is a cinch given their multiple item options.  We choose to add some meat to the platter which they were happy to do.  You should order the honey wine by the bottle and hope that your server is the woman that works there, not the dude.  I think he is mad at me for sneaking in a 6-pack with Stove the last time we went...
author: Rusty O.

description: I do love me Ethiopian food.  I've eaten here a few times and I like it.  The prices are right, the food quite tasty and the service good.  It's a small, cute, family-owned place.  I've brought a few friends here and we usually get the vegetarian sampler platter, though I'm not vegetarian.  It's just my favorite when I'm eating Ethiopian.  Anyway, I'll continue to go back for more.
author: Magdalena ..

description: Etheopian food.  Wasn't too impressed by the flavor or atmosphere in the Lower Haight location.  Haven't been back since.
author: Mitch A.

description: I was a little hesitant to try it, but now i have no idea why. Freakin tasty. I don't even remember the names, but I know we got some meat and spinach and basically just grabbed the injera (pancake-like bread that covered the plate) and dipped it into everything on the plate. I don't think there was anything edible left on the plate by the time we were done...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I would have never thought that I'd get cravings for Ethiopian.  But I do.  And this is where I go.  The portions are big, the prices are cheap, and we always get great services.  I used to come here a lot when I lived closer (I'd even stop and get it to go once in a while) and, even though I don't go nearly as often, the waitress (who may be one of the owners) always remembers me and chats a bit.  I don't love the fact that my hands smell like Ethiopian food the rest of the day but am willing to overlook that little fact ...
author: Jessica G.

description: I'm a regular at Axum. Super friendly staff (owners), excellent hearty food and a very affordable price tag.
author: eric m.

description:
so, normally, i'm not much of an ethiopean food kinda gal. i mean, where's the beef? (yes, i know that's beef, i'm just making a reference, oh nevermind...)

and so when miz loo decided upon this place for her birthday/secret bridal-pirate-robot shower, i prepared by getting a nice big bacon cheezburger with everything. (everything meaning all the toppings plus a 1/4 of a banana creme pie.)

but i have to say, the food was pretty tasty--i'm never excited about sourdough in any shape, but the spicy was nicely warming, the flavors pretty good, and i found myself eating more than my share and enjoying it. 

also, the service is great, and they are friendly awesome hosts. if you like ethiopean food, by all means, check it out.
author: eliza w.

description: I love this place. yes it is across the street from my house. But aside from its ultra convenient location, it is delicious. The staff is super nice and the tibsi chicken is tasty as a mofo. Also you cannot beat the low prices. Two people can get in and out for under $20.  The vegetarian sampler platter is sure to please because then you can try a few, I recommend the mushrooms potatoes and chick peas.
author: kristen l.

description: Ethiopian. The veggie combo platter is a good deal - gives you a taste of each of Axum's vegetarian dishes. Three of us ate heartily for $30. Impressed that the place was bustling on a Sunday night. Although I was surprised to find the most even demographic I've ever seen in a cafe/restaurant. Everyone was between 24-28 and seemed to all be post grads at Stanford. Paintings hark to Ethopia's Orthodox Church which, I learned from the menu, was founded in the 4th century.
author: Bob G.

description: For the last 7 years, I've been going to Axum and I haven't been disappointed yet. As you all know, parking is a biznatch in Lower Haight, but do not let this deter you from a good meal at a great rate. The per-person meat or veggie platters are a staple of Axum and it's what keeps me coming back. Cheers! =)
author: Be N.

description: I had a good experience here, but not a great one. What they lack in ambiance they certainly make up for in authenticity. I liked the idea of the communal platter but it's tough to get all that food with your fingers and a soggy crepe thingy. We tried a variety of things that ranged from very good to bad. I know that some things are an aquired taste and perhaps ethiopian food is not my thing, but I would suggest staying from the raw or rare (also pretty much raw) beef and the spinach dish (which comes from a can I believe). Certainly worth a try but perhaps just not my thing, and I feel obligated to mention the night cap at the bar got skipped because we all needed to clock some bathroom time.
author: M L.

description:
this is my first time having Ethiopian food so i probably won't be able to give you an expertise's taste review. 

tibsie chicken: so so yummy! 
kintishara: mushroom-licious
tumtumo:  i didn't realized it was lentil puree. good but it was like a soup.
alicha: a little lacking in flavor but it balanced out the other sides. it was weird to pick up the huge chunks of potatoes, carrots, etc with the bread. 

the honey wine was good. i'm not a big fan of the bread. i think the sourness doesn't compliment the dishes. 

i like this place because i like the manager/owner - he's really nice. i came in on the evening of Obama's State of the Union Address. he was more into speech than the customers coming in. [he didn't ignore or gave less attention to his customers but you can tell he didn't really want to step away from the television].
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
I spent most of my time at Axum wondering how it got such a high rating on Yelp. The only conclusion I could come to was that the reviewers must have never had Ethiopian food before.
I've eaten at multiple Ethiopian restaurants in Dallas, Houston, Seattle, and the Bay Area. This was not only the most tasteless food but the worst atmosphere as well. I don't understand how you can make Ethiopian food with so little spice, but they've invented it at Axum. I will never go back.
Actually, I did like the herb sauce on the salad. But a teaspoon of sauce is no reason to give them any more of my money or yours.
author: Ted H.

description: I would have given this place 4 stars if I had received better service. The food is pretty good (Not the best ethiopian I've ever had, but closer that Tempe AZ's Blue Nile), an pretty inexpensive. But we had to litterally grab the waitress when we were ready to order AND for our check. But the mushrooms that come on the veggie plate were really good.
author: Morgan S.

description:
ethiopian food is so yummy.

this place is really good, but not my fave.

i prefer massawa to axum.  but my two other ethiopian connoisseur companions liked this place better.

their bread is a little more lemony than other places, which i like.  great food for a great price.
service isn't great, but in a polite way.  they don't rush you.
not a lot of ambiance, though i wouldn't kick it out of bed.
(these pics make it look much nicer than is in reality)
author: Ge O.

description: Mmmm, Axum. Although there's another Ethiopian place literally a block from my house, I'll travel to Axum for my Ethiopian fix. I always get the vegetarian platter with some meat. The mushrooms are a favorite!
author: L N.

description: I'm not sure how they got such a good rating, unless all the other Ethiopian places in the city are abysmal. Their injera tasted like it came out of a frozen store-bought package, and their food itself was the oiliest Ethiopian I've ever had. The vegetables weren't cooked all the way through and weren't very flavorful. Overall it seemed worse than I could manage on my own. Definitely not a place to take newbies. It didn't fix my craving for Ethiopian food at all, so I'll have to try someplace else!
author: Veronica L.

description: So yummy, the flavors are really wonderfully complex. To try lots of different flavors, I like getting the vegetarian sampler and one meat dish. It's fabulous to be able to feed four really people well for under $40 in this city. The price and deliciousness even made me ignore the less-than-attentive service, which isn't a problem if you're not in a hurry.
author: Shannon R.

description: Good food --spicy and filling coupled with nearly indifferent service.  After reading some of the reviews, I am glad we paid in cash.
author: Tim G.

description: This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and I'm not sure if i enjoyed it or not. The food was interesting, like nothing i have ever eaten before. So if your looking for something new, go for it.
author: Vespa Fox C.

description: Hmmm. Eat the tibsie fish. Avoid the alicha..it has no flavor.
author: Faye P.

description: It was okay, and I'd go again since it's close to where I live, but I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to eat there.
author: Ebun O.

description: Love the food here! I recommend the vegetarian family style platter. SO good! You will eat past the point of being hungry, it's that good. The only draw back is, some times the wait staff is not that what I would call warm, more hasty. It's not something that keeps me away though, since I frequent this place about every other month or so. The prices are reasonable and the food pairs really well with a cold Corona!
author: Valencia D.

description: Don't waste your money here. This place is perhaps the most bland, tasteless African food in the city and not very kid friendly either.  A sure bet would be the African restaurant on Irving.  A world of difference in terms of quality, service and flavor. Two stars because there prices were much more reasonable than the other places.
author: M K.

description: I'm not a big fan of Ethiopian food but this place was pretty good. Agreed on the vegetarian platter. You get a lot of interesting flavors and of course eating with your hands is just plain fun. So if you do like Etheopian I would suggest this place. I'll personally be eating a burrito down the street : )
author: Steve H.

description:
My favorites are the veggie platters and the spicy lamb dish.  Their injera is nice and tangy most of the time and compliments the spiced vegetable and meat flavors so well.   

This is really delicious comfort food at affordable prices in a BASIC and cosy environment.   With the vegetarian dishes, it might be better to go earlier than later:   All the time except once, i did takeout early in the evening.  My one foray going much later in the night had the veggie combo's usual smooth liquid consistancy to be a thick heavy paste instead, its moistness evaporated like it had sat in the pot for too long.  They need to cut their potatoes into smaller pieces to lessen the cooking time and prevent earlier orders (5:30-6:00pm) not to be undercooked and crunchy.  I find early orders to be the best quality overall so I just avoid the potato now.  This review might sound critical, but these are only minor things I'm pointing out to make the dining experience as wonderful as possible.  Axum is my staple and favorite ethiopian place for the monthly if not weekly Ethiopian cravings.  Certain meat dishes, like the lamb ones,  are always freshly cooked and piping hot per order.  

Parking can be really difficult at times, that's the main drawback.   

For people unfamiliar with ethiopian food:  it's to be eaten with your hands.  Unfortunately, I've seen super fastidious unadventureous diners, taken to other ethiopian restaurants (in more expensive settings)  being unable to get over the eat with the hands and no utensils concept.  

If you are familiar with Ethiopian food, then Axum won't disappoint you.  It may become one of your favorite places to eat for this cuisine.

-------
3/27/07
Not happy.  Their portions have shrunk considerably.  To about half the amount of food they use to dish out.  These were the vegetarian items.  No idea if they did the same with the meat dishes.  No complaints about the flavor of the food.
author: Animal K.

description: Hubby thinks this is his #1 restaurant of all time. Almost without fail, the food is excellent and really flavorful. We bring out of towners here alot with no complaints - even picky eaters! My favorite is zingine (beef) - they have great vegan choices too.
author: Jen H.

description: usually busy, food is worth it though, as well as the experience.  If your lucky the boss will come out and play the Krar for the table.  If you try to order the same thing as someone else they won't let you, as it's a group experience.  Some Ethiopian beer as well as Honey wine is worth a try.  The people make it a great.
author: Michael I.

description:
I order the same thing every time I come here: the veggie platter for two.  And no, I don't eat it all myself, but I do my best--elbowing Kelsey, gently nudging her away as I scoop up the last bits of delicious legumes, greens, and mushrooms.  In fact, pretty much every time Kelsey and I try to figure out where to eat, I say, "Axum!" and Kelsey says, "not again!"  But that's fine, because absence makes the heart grow fonder, or whatever.  

Anyway, their veggie platter is delicious and very, very filling.  The staff is friendly when they recognize you, but they can be a little chilly toward newcomers or "me, me, me"-type customers--which is fine by me, as I'm always creeped out by super-friendly (usually forced) service.  I like my servers to keep it real.  And I like humble customers.  

Axum also has Harar beer, which, when I feel like living it up (an entree AND a drink?  No way!), I order.  It's sweet, it's good, and it's a nice way to wash down your injera.  

I deduct one star only because their spinach tasted a bit rotten once (out of roughly a million times, so the odds are slim; but still, if I'm paying for it, I want to be able to eat it without worrying about what will happen to me later).
author: Alyson Y.

description: I've eaten at just about every Ethiopean restaurant in the city and this one hands down is the best!  I always get the Vegi combo and the lamb.  I crave this place!!!
author: Michele G.

description: My favorite dish is definitely the lamb.  I think the flavors are really good, and I really think it is much better in comparison to the other Ethiopian places I've been to in the city.  You can't beat the price, and it is definitely fun to catch up with friends over the communal platter.
author: Julie B.

description: i so want this place to be better.  it is so close to my house and i love ethiopian food, but they have just never done it for me.  the food is ok, but certainly not great.  i have had better.  but what has gotten me each time i have gone here is the poor service.  many times i felt like i was actively ignored and when we did get service it was with a put-out attitude.  wish it was better.
author: Patrick M.

description: Best Ethiopian in the City.  Order the veggie platter and a pitcher of beer - feeds three for under $20.
author: Mike G M.

description: This is the first Ethiopian restaurant I EVER went to. And it can also be my last and always, just like Barry White used ta say. The sega tibs is TO DIE FOR and I love the staff.
author: Doug W.

description: Doesn't get any better than this.  Amazing food, good vibe, staff that makes you feel like you're family.
author: Rocky M.

description:
The food was fine. Service was barely mediocre, for this reason I did not tip. It appears on my bank statement that the owner took it upon himself to charge me a 5 dollar tip after the fact. I'll be talking with the guy soon, busted.

Food wasn't even that special for the "best Ethiopian food" in SF. It was also expensive so I suggest splitting one dish with a person, but I guess those are just Haight prices.
author: John M.

description: Deeeeelicious! This was my introduction to Ethiopian food, and I've been coming back ever since. Cheap eats, friendly folks, although the service can be a bit. . . . mellow.
author: Michelle O.

description: Cheap, good African cuisine.  Very friendly staff.  Some things are better than others, so now we order alacarte, and it's still a bargain.  After 10-plus years living around the corner, I don't go there as often as before.
author: Rob B.

description: As a big fan of ethiopian cuisine, Axum Cafe wins based on price and taste here in the city.  They have very good Injera, which is the spongy fermented bread.  I would have given Axum 4-5 stars, but they aren't a top rating because of the slow service.  It's a trade off, but if you're not in a hurry during peak dinner hours, stop by and be sure to wash your hands!
author: Richard P.

description: My friends and I just visited Axum Cafe this past weekend. The service was horrible. The women was condescending when we weren't completely clear on how to order the vegetarian platter. She rolled her eyes at us! Plus she didn't check on us during the meal, didn't fill our water glasses and was stingy with the napkins. To top it all off, they overcharged us when they ran our credit card. We decided to leave just a 10% tip because of the poor service, and she adjusted it to 20%! What a cheat! Good thing we checked later. Thumbs waaaaay down!
author: AB T.

description:
the food is really good i got the veggi sampler and i share with my other two friendsand the price i dont remmenber as well but was around $8 and its pretty good they also have the honey beer or good bottles of wine.
but the thing is this the service SUCKS for real we waiit for around 5-10 min since the waiter (that is also the cashier and dont know what else) ask us for our drinks.
the places is little but i will say it again the food is really tasty
author: David m.

description:
I'd never had Ethiopian food before, and had in fact been warned against it.  I was pleasantly surprised from all the horror stories I'd heard, but still am not a huge fan.

My friends and I split the vegetarian platter, which had a good variety of different veggie purees and mixes, though nothing too out of the ordinary.  I liked the cabbage dish in particular.  Eaten with the odd flavored sourdough-esque crepe, and sans utensils, it made for an interesting experience.

Our server was pretty friendly, though she brought the check soon after the food, which kind of made us feel rushed, though there was plenty of open tables and no one waiting...

Try a glass of the honey wine.

Overall it was good to try something new, but Im not sure I will be rushing back any time soon.
author: Christophe B.

description: Living across the street makes me & my feller regulars here. We keep going back and it consistently ranges between a 4 to 5 stars. The people who run the restaurant are genuine; the food is prompt and the place is clean. If you're looking to be dazzled by decor or if you're a princess that needs to be doted on, well, these kind people have better things to do (like cook great food). It is a treat to go here and every time we order the same thing: veggie platter for two and we haven't gotten tired of it yet!
author: Zasu T.

description: allways my favorite Ethopian food.  VERY casual and delicious!  One of the great family restaurants in the city
author: scott t.

description: "cheap, tasty, spicy, ethnic" niche is filled very well here. Extra points for having a varied, apparently healthy option (vegetarian sampler for n people).
author: R E.

description:
Once, I lived in a small college town in the Midwest.  Ethopian food was fancy.  Ooh, you ate it with your fingers while your folks shelled out $13 for a vegetarian entree.    Then I moved to SF and was initially seduced by the inexpensive fare of Axum cafe: delightful, until, like Tina Turner after returning, black-eyed, again and again to Ike, I finally declared myself free of my relationship with Axum Cafe.  The final straw: an attempt to cater a party with veggie-friendly options while supporting local business, to which I met utter indifference from the staff/owner(?) waitron I spoke to on a slow afternoon.  A brief summary:

I: "I'd like to cater a small get-together, with food for about seven people."

Middle-aged waitron:  "You can get the combo for five plus the combo for two, or the combo for four plus the combo for three."

I:  "Yes, but each combo becomes less expensive with the more people it serves.  What would it be for a combo for seven?"

Middle-aged waitron: "There's no combo for seven"

I:  "Is there anyone else I can talk to?"

Middle-aged waitron: "Nobody else is here."

After a couple years of hiatus, I finally return to Axum.  The table's order vanishes as the adjacent table is seated and served while my dinner companion and I wait for half an hour.  Finally, a staff member (the proprietor?) asks what we've been waiting for as middle-aged waitron serves other tables.  Finally our food arrives, and we pledge never again to bother with Axum.  There are plenty of other, tastier Ethiopean/Eritrean joints in this town, two of them just up Haight Street.  We'll be going there from now onl.
author: Eric K.

description: This was my first experience with Ethiopian food, and I came away impressed.  The restaurant is decor is minimal and pretty casual, but they were playing some good jazz when I ate there, which was a nice touch.  We had a group of 5 and all ordered different things, so it was nice that the food comes out "family style" to share, I got to try everything.  I was a little uncomfortable at first without utensils, but grew a liking to the spongy bread that you pick up the food with.  The food had just the right amount of spice, and the availability of ginger beer was a plus.  The shrimp dish in particular was very good.  I would definitely go back next time I'm in the area.
author: Grainger G.

description: This is a total dive restaurant but the food is reliably good. Great for vegetarians.
author: mark m.

description: Food was o.k, not the best Ethiopian food, but not the worst either.  Service was abysmal though.  The waitress couldn't have seemed less interested, never brought me my beer and couldn't be found when we wanted more injera.  I can usually excuse bad service in slightly dive-y plases, but when we tried to pay with a credit card the waitress said "I don't think so, credit card machine broken" and walked away without an apology.  Luckily we were able to scrape together enough cash to pay for the meal, but we had to hit up an ATM down the street to get cab fare.  I won't be back.
author: Rich C.

description: Great food and great value. We ordered the Vegetarian Platter for Two ... wow, only $14 bucks, very flavorful and plenty filling. The atmosphere is a little lacking, but all in all a great choice. Will definitely go again.
author: Michael C.

description: Axum serves the best ethiopian chow I've had, and it's super-cheap, even with a bottle of "honey wine".  The service may not be up to Gary Danko standards, but for the price, what the hell do you expect?
author: Brent H.

description: Now there is one thing I really love.  That is Ethiopian food.  I've heard a lot about Axum a lot from a lot of people - they raved!  But I was very disappointed when I actually tried the food.  Overall it was delicious, but the bread - usually spongy and delicious - was dry.  I was hoping I got a bad batch.  I'm sure I'll give it another try, but I'll try other places before I do.
author: Jenny M.

description: T-R-I-F-E. ordered the veggie combo and the tibsi shrimp. what came out was soup on a plate and shrimp that they didn't even bother to take the tails off of. sometimes you can just tell when a restaurant is catering to namblas. how? it wasn't even spicy. at all. no thanks.
author: schitzen h.

description: This is where i always take friends who are in town wanting to try some Ethopian food.  It took awhile to figure out what to order and what goes well with what.  Obviously it's a shared plate and trying to figure out how much food for everyone is enough is a concern.  However the food is always good, some dishes better than the others.... great little place and fits perfectly on Haight.
author: Al C.

description: Very good and cheap.  My nod goes to Massawa though.
author: Vernon B.

description: The veggie platter is great. so many different flavors and I've always eyed those huge platters of food when i walk by. not to mention, being forced to eat with your hands is always fun. Too bad the iron bars covering the entire exterior and neon glow from the cheap beer signs makes the place feel like more like a prison cafeteria than a restaurant. Also, I don't recommend the Honey wine unless you enjoy that homemade moonshine taste in your alcohol.
author: Ehren D.

description:
I guess, I'm not a fan of the place.  some parts of the plate were good though.  I think it was the beef and Lamb and some other mush stuff...

One reviewer said they had to toilet hop their way home...I didn't so that was good...
author: Alterego M.

description: eat ethiopian food with your hands, surrounded by sophisticated duders with glasses
author: alec m.

description: I have visited this establishment a few times. Always great service and exellent food. Portions are large and the quality of food is definitly worth ever dollar. I've tried the menu and everything is good- no negatives to this place minus one.. smallish eating area. Enjoy!
author: Chris S.

description: this place is magnificent - partly because the food is so good, and also because it is in a convenient location.  sure the parking sucks in the lower haight - so take the 22, 7, 6, 71, N or J, all of which stop within a few blocks of the restaurant.
author: Lauren G.

description: I love the delicious food here.  Tasty potatoes, carrots, chicken, salad, spices, etc.  Nice and filling.  I love eating with my hands!  Warm, colorful atmosphere.  Our waiter was so nice and friendly.  Great service.  I will be back many times.
author: Tuesday J.

description: i can't believe i live two blocks away and it has taken me over a year to eat here.  i was walking by last night though with my roommates and we popped on in.  and boy am i sorry i passed this place up so often.  it was pretty damn good, and who doesn't love to eat with their hands?  silverware is just so restrictive sometimes you know...anyways i am a newly found fan.  p.s. they serve pitchers...
author: Katie M.

description: YUM! The place is simple but the food is very, very good...slightly on the spicier side but the flavors were wonderful. I just moved here from Seattle and there are some AMAZING places there. This isn't as good but it's up there.
author: Hoa S.

description: this place has the best, cheapest vegitarian food in the city.  once i left my purse behind and the waitress/owner/supermodel ran me down in the street, several blocks away, to return it to me.  they've had the same chef for awhile, so the kitchen is very consistent.  sometimes i have eaten leftovers from axum the next day- cold, for breakfast- and it's still good.  you can take kids there.  did i mention that the waitress/owner looks like a supermodel?
author: Kathleen R.

description: i heard this place was like hella good but i got food that (i am being serious) tasted like raw ground beef and pine needles.
author: Lisa M.

description: i really have a soft spot in my heart (and bowels) for axum. i used to LOVE this place. Until i started getting explosive bowel movements after i ate there. funny thing is, it just all of a sudden started happening. and i think it perfectly correlated to when their food started all of a sudden getting untolerably spicy. the spicy factor here is variable....but don't get me wrong, the food is always tasty. what happens afterwards is fair game. (5 stars for food + 1 star for "afterwards")/2 = 3 stars total.
author: bloopie s.

description:
The food here is decent and its cheap, but the last time I went here with my wife we got some pretty odd and awful service.  I don't know if the woman running the place that night was mad at her husband, but if you were in a couple you got a heaping dish of disdain with you order.  I thought maybe it was us at first (although I couldn't figure out why), but then I realized there was another couple getting the cold shoulder and they were having the same reaction.  
     Other tables that had mixed parties or were maybe a group of guys got treated real well, but then she would change when she got to our table.  This may be a coincidence, but I also noticed that the other couple, like my wife and I, were mixed (asian/white).  So I couldn't help but feel we were getting the shaft for being a couple or a mixed couple.
    They're not the only Ethiopian restaurant in the city, but they are probably the cheapest. Yet I'm more than willing to shed a couple of bills for some decent service.
author: Sean B.

description: I've loved Ethiopian food for years, and I love Axum. The veggie plate makes a great dinner for 2. It's inexpensive and always worth a trip to the Lower Haight.
author: Marc C.

description: really really consistently good. no-frills atmosphere and service, but incredibly delicious food.
author: Cristabel L.

description: yes--came here with a friend the past weekend and got what i expected--very good and tasty Ethiopian fare. we had the veggie platter for 2, along with some good ginger ale that complemented the meal pretty well. the lady server knew my friend from way back when and was nice to her, but seemed pretty cold toward us afterward. i'd still go back there if the parking wasn't ridiculously difficult.
author: Chris C.

description: Mmm. This was only my second ever ethiopian place.  I saw it and thought mmm i want to try that. It seemed to have good reviews and was by my house. So, i took my date there, she'd never had ethiopian food before. We loved it. Everything is cheap. The most expensive thing is the shrimp, which is $12, but everything ranges between 6-10 usually.  They also have yummy ethiopian honey wine which is a little thick, strong, and very sweet.  I had the veggie combo, with the cabbage/potato/carrot dish, the spinach dish, and the chickpea dish. It also came with salad and plenty of bread.  She had the lamb, which came with salad and the chickpea.  Such large helpings!  The bad thing is you cant get a combo with a meat dish. But you can get meat and then add a veggie on for $3.  I talked about how good this place was so much after going on thursday that on saturday my friends made me take them.  One friend and i got talked into getting the veggie sampler for 2 instead of getting 2 combos.   I wouldnt do that again, i think we ended up with less food, and the bread got soggier. I did get to try the last 2 veggies - mushrooms which i didnt like (but then again i dont like mushrooms) but tameka did, and lentils which neither of us liked (and i do generally like lentils).  Another friend tried the chicken and liked it, and more lambs were liked too. So overall, yum.
author: Merredith L.

description: this place was horrible, oil pooled off all the food, and they give you one small piece of injera to eat all of it, turns out that one piece was enough, we didn't finish anyway. ugh.
author: Jared Z.

description: the first time i tried ethiopian was here and i was a little nervous but actually loved it!  must get  the vegetarian platter - money...every time.  i also tried a lamb dish which was also delicious!  you're definitely going there for the food not the ambiance - have no expectations.  some of my fav restaurants are those hole in the wall sf restaurants aka gems.  i did try ethiopian in jersey and the food was just as consistent so i have something to compare to.
author: Meredith K.

description: what to say?  mmmmm...it's really good ethiopian food.  the service is super spotty.  last time i was there they totally misunderstood us and i got my husband's beef in the middle of my veggie platter.  hello?  i know nobody is responsible for what i eat but me, but if i order the vegetarian combo, maybe at least ASK if it's okay to put dead cow in the middle?  i've been there many many times and have never had that happen before.  the decor is nothing to mention except for a really awesome haight ashbury board game framed near the bathroom.  but the food is SO DELICIOUS i just keep going back!  plus it's so close to my house.  yum.
author: kate s.

description: My Friends and I went to Axum based on the Yelp reviews...and ordered the vegetarian sampler based on the reviews...oh what a great choice......delicious, a little bit of everything and cheap!
author: Joy Y.

description:
this was my first ethiopian food experience, ever!  and it was completely fantastic.  like everybody said the service is a little iffy..but there was literally one waitress for the entire restaurant so I can see why she would be slightly frazzled having to deal with everyone.

the 6 of us ordered the vegetarian sampling platter and a chicken and lamb dish as well..it came out on a plate the size of ...gosh I dunno what it would be the size of, i've never seen such a large platter in my entire life.  okay anyway, it's a really big plate!  then we all got a separate plate of sour pancakey bread apparently called injera and dug in with our hands.  completely a different dining experience for me, but i really enjoyed it!  I even hate spicy food and ate everything anyway because it was so good.

i told my mother about it later on and she said "what's so great about ethiopian food?  look they're all starving, it can't be that great!"  oh mom..you're so cute.
author: jozilla w.

description: my first experience with ethiopian food - so i really have nothing to compare it to. however, my girlfriend does - so i take her word for it. so we went here on friday. we ordered the 5-item vegetarian platter, which came to us very fast! the plate was tasty and it was pretty cheaply priced. my only knock on this place was the waiter forgetting our drink orders. our drinks came to us half-way through our meal. that doesn't bother me too much because the good food and the price made up for it. i will be back.
author: James J.

description: super low key place, but i couldn't image an Ethiopian place fancied up anyway (was that judgemental of me? well i guess so, huh?) i went with like 5 other people and ordered family style. a giganator dish was brought out to us with all this stewed stuff on it. and twas served with some squishy sourish pancakey like thing that you rip apart and eat the stuff with, much like naan for your Indian. the server wasn't the greatest but considering the surroundings of the place, i didn't quite expect excellence anyhow.
author: Regina C.

description: ahhhhhhhh, tickle and twist my taste buds.  this place hits the sweet spot...if you like spicy food.  there is no place as good in sf then Axum for Ethiopian food, always a smile of satisfaction when i leave.  I knew eating with my hands would be appropriate at some point.
author: erica u.

description: Good ethiopian food.  I had the lentils, lamb and one of the spicy grilled beefs.  All flavorful, especially the lentils.  Although I've had better lamb at an Ethiopian place before, this was still good.  The beef was quite flavorful and the bread was light.
author: Kristen T.

description: the food is great and i crave it.  the service is on a range from good to just ok. it have never been down right bad. but its hard to find a place that is super packed and still get good service and not have your waiter running around still doing a great job.
author: Morgan G.

description: this place rocks! nice vegie combo. the best ethiopian in the bay area. friendly service.
author: Maximilian D.

description: The service was quick, in fact it arrived in less than 2 minutes and so we were pretty sure it was pre made. Thats not a problem for me. But the food quality was definitely mediocre. We had the veggie platter, very ordinary compared to massawa/assab. Ambience isnt much to talk about. Its in the Haight, so parking isnt the easiest.. 2.5 stars
author: A A.

description:
3.5 stars
I've been to this place twice. The first time, we tried to order but we got it all wrong and the server (who is also one of the owners, I think), basically said "Um, no", and then he left for about half an hour. Apparently, you have to order in number of portions, and we tried to do too few since we weren't that hungry. When we finally got our food, it was really good. The injera is like a sour, spongy pancake that you use to scoop up all the different types of ....vegetable and meat dips/sauces/purees/stews. 
Anyway, I went again tonight, and this time we knew how to order! I felt so great about myself when he nodded approvingly after we ordered correctly.
So yeah, the service was much better this time, the woman who mostly served us was really nice and checked up on us a lot. The food is strongly spiced and very filling (order less than you think you'll need--if they let you!). It wasn't great (hence the 3.5 stars), but I'd definitely go back, especially since it was pretty cheap.
author: Vanessa L.

description: This place was adequate.  The food was fine, the people there were nice enough.   I love Ethiopian food and have had it a few times before and i would say this was the most mediocre of my experiences.  Except whatever #2 on the menu was was really good.  The rest sure was food.  It tasted okay enough.  One disappointment was the paucity of choices.  Perhaps i have been spoiled by being offered a fairly wide selection of items at other Ethiopian restaraunts.  There were only 5 vegetarian options and of the meat options, all but two were prepared the exact same way.  Also, the bread (i forgot the name) was cold.  The nice thing about Ethiopian food though is that it is fun to eat with friends and that makes up for a lot of shortcomings.  Despite the general feeling of "meh" this place created, i still enjoyed myself.   I would say if you are in the area and want Ethiopian, this place is fine, but if you are traveling to get to it, give a different place a shot.
author: courtney e.

description: Haven't been there in a couple of years but when I used to live around the corner, I used to eat there at least once a month for several years.  Consistently tastey and good value.
author: sfnewyorker Y.

description: I love love this place! So, okay, the place is a bit austere (and drafty at times) but the food is to die for. It's one of those cuisines that I crave often and can eat almost every day. The meat dishes are great and spicy and I always leave full and happy. Careful with the injera bread though - for all its thinness and lightness it does make you feel full right away. Pace yourself!
author: Lee P.

description: I've been to some of the best restaurants in the Bay Area (including the French Laundry, Kokkari, Town Hall, Salt House, Chaya Brasserie, Aqua, One Market) and I can attest to the fact that I'd still consider Axum one of the best restaurants in the Bay Area and for its kind. And I'm a very demanding customer, to start with.  I won't go back to a restaurant that fails to deliver (a recent example: COI that just got a one Michelin star and absolutely sucked in every way or UNICORN which is overrated in many ways or even SCOTT's Seafood in Jack London Square). I've been going to Axum for many, many years, I think close to, if not more than, 10 years. Some of the reviews to some of the Ethiopian restaurants contain exaggerations. Axum is awesome! And that's not an exaggeration.  Flavor, spices, service, atmosphere (casual neighborhood feeling with some ethnic aura away from the hectic rushed lifestyle) -- all perfect! Tipsie chicken is my favorite item and all the veggies rock! And the salad dressing is superb! I go there often and fight over the food with my friends.  And I love the family that owns the restaurant.  I remember for a while the mother was pregnant all the time (I think they have 4 or 5 kids).  This is a very warm restaurant with excellent food.  And the so-called "bland" bread that some reviewers have mentioned, it's ironic: this is the restaurant's introduction of whole wheat injera -- in obvious response to health conscious San Franciscans' lifestyle and demands.
author: Yanni G.

description:
my first experience at an Ethiopian restaurant and it will not be my last.  that being said i am going to be conservative with a 4 star review because i have nothing to base it on but i have to say with all caps WOW.  
the service is pretty much non-existent so don't expect it.  the food was amazing.  i am still thinking about it to tell you the truth.  everything about the meal was delicious and i was really surprised by how this very unassuming place delivered.  we had the TISIE LAMB, TUMTUMO, KINTISHARA, and HAMLI.  my only complaint about any of the dishes was that the lamb was definitely overcooked and tough.  everything else though was amazing.  it kind of seems to me and maybe i am wrong about this but Ethiopian food is similar to Indian food and i think and i feel like the vegetarian dishes are where it's at for Indian food, and I'm thinking, this holds true for Ethiopian as well.
what really surprised me the most was the injera bread and the way the sour tartness complimented the dishes each a little differently.
i cant wait to go back and sample more of the items.
i think this might end up as a 5 star spot if the other Ethiopian joints on yelp don't live up to this one.   what i liked was the flavors exotic but not overpowering and very well balanced.  the value was fantastic as well.  dinner for 2 with 1 glass of honey wine and 1 Ethiopian beer was 39 bucks with tip.  although as i was walking by this place i was tempted to go into Baghdad nights but that's another night's adventure away.
author: Anthony Y.

description: I have to admit, my first experience with Ethiopian-type cuisine was at Assab, so that may have spoiled me a little bit, but this place is definitely comparable.  The actual place is your standard San Francisco restaurant, nothing overly elegant or exotic but definitely comfortable and clean.  Service was limited to one waiter on this particular night (who I have a slight suspicion must be either the owner or somehow affiliated with the company financially, since he seemed pretty delighted when we mentioned that we found the place by looking online).  I ordered the fish entree and my friends had a 2 person platter of assorted vegetables.  Overall the food was pretty good, not quite as flavorful or plentiful as Assab, but definitely worth the price (about $12-13 a person).  The waiter seemed pretty friendly and even went out of his way to get us change (he ran all the way out to his car in the rain).  The building could benefit from some better lighting (it was pretty dark on an overcast day inside).  I would definitely recommend the place to anyone interested in trying out Ethiopian food in the area, but if you're looking for the best-of-the-best, I would recommend making a reservation at Assab and checking that place out first.  Definitely cannot complain about Axum though, overall a nice place to eat some good food.
author: Luis M.

description: great food, friendly service, perhaps a bit overpriced. i like the veggie dish with potatoes and cabbage.
author: Horrible H.
